text: In other studies you go as far as others have gone before you, and there is nothing more to know; but in a scientific pursuit there is continual food for discovery and wonder.
author: MWS

text: A mind of moderate capacity which closely pursues one study must infallibly arrive at great proficiency in that study; and I, who continually sought the attainment of one object of pursuit and was solely wrapped up in this, improved so rapidly that at the end of two years I made some discoveries in the improvement of some chemical instruments, which procured me great esteem and admiration at the university.
author: MWS

text: When I had arrived at this point and had become as well acquainted with the theory and practice of natural philosophy as depended on the lessons of any of the professors at Ingolstadt, my residence there being no longer conducive to my improvements, I thought of returning to my friends and my native town, when an incident happened that protracted my stay.
author: MWS

text: One of the phenomena which had peculiarly attracted my attention was the structure of the human frame, and, indeed, any animal endued with life.
author: MWS

text: Whence, I often asked myself, did the principle of life proceed?
author: MWS

text: It was a bold question, and one which has ever been considered as a mystery; yet with how many things are we upon the brink of becoming acquainted, if cowardice or carelessness did not restrain our inquiries.
author: MWS

text: I revolved these circumstances in my mind and determined thenceforth to apply myself more particularly to those branches of natural philosophy which relate to physiology.
author: MWS

text: Unless I had been animated by an almost supernatural enthusiasm, my application to this study would have been irksome and almost intolerable.
author: MWS

text: To examine the causes of life, we must first have recourse to death.
author: MWS

text: I became acquainted with the science of anatomy, but this was not sufficient; I must also observe the natural decay and corruption of the human body.
author: MWS

text: In my education my father had taken the greatest precautions that my mind should be impressed with no supernatural horrors.
author: MWS

text: I do not ever remember to have trembled at a tale of superstition or to have feared the apparition of a spirit.
author: MWS

text: Darkness had no effect upon my fancy, and a churchyard was to me merely the receptacle of bodies deprived of life, which, from being the seat of beauty and strength, had become food for the worm.
author: MWS

text: Now I was led to examine the cause and progress of this decay and forced to spend days and nights in vaults and charnel-houses.
author: MWS

text: My attention was fixed upon every object the most insupportable to the delicacy of the human feelings.
author: MWS

text: I saw how the fine form of man was degraded and wasted; I beheld the corruption of death succeed to the blooming cheek of life; I saw how the worm inherited the wonders of the eye and brain.
author: MWS

text: I paused, examining and analysing all the minutiae of causation, as exemplified in the change from life to death, and death to life, until from the midst of this darkness a sudden light broke in upon me—a light so brilliant and wondrous, yet so simple, that while I became dizzy with the immensity of the prospect which it illustrated, I was surprised that among so many men of genius who had directed their inquiries towards the same science, that I alone should be reserved to discover so astonishing a secret.
author: MWS

text: Remember, I am not recording the vision of a madman.
author: MWS

text: The sun does not more certainly shine in the heavens than that which I now affirm is true.
author: MWS

text: Some miracle might have produced it, yet the stages of the discovery were distinct and probable.
author: MWS

text: After days and nights of incredible labour and fatigue, I succeeded in discovering the cause of generation and life; nay, more, I became myself capable of bestowing animation upon lifeless matter.
author: MWS

text: The astonishment which I had at first experienced on this discovery soon gave place to delight and rapture.
author: MWS

text: After so much time spent in painful labour, to arrive at once at the summit of my desires was the most gratifying consummation of my toils.
author: MWS

text: But this discovery was so great and overwhelming that all the steps by which I had been progressively led to it were obliterated, and I beheld only the result.
author: MWS

text: What had been the study and desire of the wisest men since the creation of the world was now within my grasp.
author: MWS

text: Not that, like a magic scene, it all opened upon me at once:  the information I had obtained was of a nature rather to direct my endeavours so soon as I should point them towards the object of my search than to exhibit that object already accomplished.
author: MWS

text: I was like the Arabian who had been buried with the dead and found a passage to life, aided only by one glimmering and seemingly ineffectual light.
author: MWS

text: I see by your eagerness and the wonder and hope which your eyes express, my friend, that you expect to be informed of the secret with which I am acquainted; that cannot be; listen patiently until the end of my story, and you will easily perceive why I am reserved upon that subject.
author: MWS

text: I will not lead you on, unguarded and ardent as I then was, to your destruction and infallible misery.
author: MWS

text: Learn from me, if not by my precepts, at least by my example, how dangerous is the acquirement of knowledge and how much happier that man is who believes his native town to be the world, than he who aspires to become greater than his nature will allow.
author: MWS

text: When I found so astonishing a power placed within my hands, I hesitated a long time concerning the manner in which I should employ it.
author: MWS

text: Although I possessed the capacity of bestowing animation, yet to prepare a frame for the reception of it, with all its intricacies of fibres, muscles, and veins, still remained a work of inconceivable difficulty and labour.
author: MWS

text: I doubted at first whether I should attempt the creation of a being like myself, or one of simpler organization; but my imagination was too much exalted by my first success to permit me to doubt of my ability to give life to an animal as complex and wonderful as man.
author: MWS

text: The materials at present within my command hardly appeared adequate to so arduous an undertaking, but I doubted not that I should ultimately succeed.
author: MWS

text: I prepared myself for a multitude of reverses; my operations might be incessantly baffled, and at last my work be imperfect, yet when I considered the improvement which every day takes place in science and mechanics, I was encouraged to hope my present attempts would at least lay the foundations of future success.
author: MWS

text: Nor could I consider the magnitude and complexity of my plan as any argument of its impracticability.
author: MWS

text: It was with these feelings that I began the creation of a human being.
author: MWS

text: As the minuteness of the parts formed a great hindrance to my speed, I resolved, contrary to my first intention, to make the being of a gigantic stature, that is to say, about eight feet in height, and proportionably large.
author: MWS

text: After having formed this determination and having spent some months in successfully collecting and arranging my materials, I began.
author: MWS

text: No one can conceive the variety of feelings which bore me onwards, like a hurricane, in the first enthusiasm of success.
author: MWS

text: Life and death appeared to me ideal bounds, which I should first break through, and pour a torrent of light into our dark world.
author: MWS

text: A new species would bless me as its creator and source; many happy and excellent natures would owe their being to me.
author: MWS

text: No father could claim the gratitude of his child so completely as I should deserve theirs.
author: MWS

text: Pursuing these reflections, I thought that if I could bestow animation upon lifeless matter, I might in process of time (although I now found it impossible) renew life where death had apparently devoted the body to corruption.
author: MWS

text: These thoughts supported my spirits, while I pursued my undertaking with unremitting ardour.
author: MWS

text: My cheek had grown pale with study, and my person had become emaciated with confinement.
author: MWS

text: Sometimes, on the very brink of certainty, I failed; yet still I clung to the hope which the next day or the next hour might realise.
author: MWS

text: One secret which I alone possessed was the hope to which I had dedicated myself; and the moon gazed on my midnight labours, while, with unrelaxed and breathless eagerness, I pursued nature to her hiding-places.
author: MWS

text: Who shall conceive the horrors of my secret toil as I dabbled among the unhallowed damps of the grave or tortured the living animal to animate the lifeless clay?
author: MWS

text: My limbs now tremble, and my eyes swim with the remembrance; but then a resistless and almost frantic impulse urged me forward; I seemed to have lost all soul or sensation but for this one pursuit.
author: MWS

text: It was indeed but a passing trance, that only made me feel with renewed acuteness so soon as, the unnatural stimulus ceasing to operate, I had returned to my old habits.
author: MWS

text: I collected bones from charnel-houses and disturbed, with profane fingers, the tremendous secrets of the human frame.
author: MWS

text: In a solitary chamber, or rather cell, at the top of the house, and separated from all the other apartments by a gallery and staircase, I kept my workshop of filthy creation; my eyeballs were starting from their sockets in attending to the details of my employment.
author: MWS

text: The dissecting room and the slaughter-house furnished many of my materials; and often did my human nature turn with loathing from my occupation, whilst, still urged on by an eagerness which perpetually increased, I brought my work near to a conclusion.
author: MWS

text: The summer months passed while I was thus engaged, heart and soul, in one pursuit.
author: MWS

text: It was a most beautiful season; never did the fields bestow a more plentiful harvest or the vines yield a more luxuriant vintage, but my eyes were insensible to the charms of nature.
author: MWS

text: And the same feelings which made me neglect the scenes around me caused me also to forget those friends who were so many miles absent, and whom I had not seen for so long a time.
author: MWS

text: I knew my silence disquieted them, and I well remembered the words of my father:  “I know that while you are pleased with yourself you will think of us with affection, and we shall hear regularly from you.
author: MWS

text: You must pardon me if I regard any interruption in your correspondence as a proof that your other duties are equally neglected.”  I knew well therefore what would be my father’s feelings, but I could not tear my thoughts from my employment, loathsome in itself, but which had taken an irresistible hold of my imagination.
author: MWS

text: I wished, as it were, to procrastinate all that related to my feelings of affection until the great object, which swallowed up every habit of my nature, should be completed.
author: MWS

text: I then thought that my father would be unjust if he ascribed my neglect to vice or faultiness on my part, but I am now convinced that he was justified in conceiving that I should not be altogether free from blame.
author: MWS

text: A human being in perfection ought always to preserve a calm and peaceful mind and never to allow passion or a transitory desire to disturb his tranquillity.
author: MWS

text: I do not think that the pursuit of knowledge is an exception to this rule.
author: MWS

text: If the study to which you apply yourself has a tendency to weaken your affections and to destroy your taste for those simple pleasures in which no alloy can possibly mix, then that study is certainly unlawful, that is to say, not befitting the human mind.
author: MWS

text: If this rule were always observed; if no man allowed any pursuit whatsoever to interfere with the tranquillity of his domestic affections, Greece had not been enslaved, Cæsar would have spared his country, America would have been discovered more gradually, and the empires of Mexico and Peru had not been destroyed.
author: MWS

text: But I forget that I am moralizing in the most interesting part of my tale, and your looks remind me to proceed.
author: MWS

text: My father made no reproach in his letters and only took notice of my silence by inquiring into my occupations more particularly than before.
author: MWS

text: Winter, spring, and summer passed away during my labours; but I did not watch the blossom or the expanding leaves—sights which before always yielded me supreme delight—so deeply was I engrossed in my occupation.
author: MWS

text: The leaves of that year had withered before my work drew near to a close, and now every day showed me more plainly how well I had succeeded.
author: MWS

text: But my enthusiasm was checked by my anxiety, and I appeared rather like one doomed by slavery to toil in the mines, or any other unwholesome trade than an artist occupied by his favourite employment.
author: MWS

text: Every night I was oppressed by a slow fever, and I became nervous to a most painful degree; the fall of a leaf startled me, and I shunned my fellow creatures as if I had been guilty of a crime.
author: MWS

text: Sometimes I grew alarmed at the wreck I perceived that I had become; the energy of my purpose alone sustained me: my labours would soon end, and I believed that exercise and amusement would then drive away incipient disease; and I promised myself both of these when my creation should be complete.
author: MWS

text: Chapter 5  It was on a dreary night of November that I beheld the accomplishment of my toils.
author: MWS

text: With an anxiety that almost amounted to agony, I collected the instruments of life around me, that I might infuse a spark of being into the lifeless thing that lay at my feet.
author: MWS

text: It was already one in the morning; the rain pattered dismally against the panes, and my candle was nearly burnt out, when, by the glimmer of the half-extinguished light, I saw the dull yellow eye of the creature open; it breathed hard, and a convulsive motion agitated its limbs.
author: MWS

text: How can I describe my emotions at this catastrophe, or how delineate the wretch whom with such infinite pains and care I had endeavoured to form?
author: MWS

text: His limbs were in proportion, and I had selected his features as beautiful.
author: MWS

text: His yellow skin scarcely covered the work of muscles and arteries beneath; his hair was of a lustrous black, and flowing; his teeth of a pearly whiteness; but these luxuriances only formed a more horrid contrast with his watery eyes, that seemed almost of the same colour as the dun-white sockets in which they were set, his shrivelled complexion and straight black lips.
author: MWS

text: The different accidents of life are not so changeable as the feelings of human nature.
author: MWS

text: I had worked hard for nearly two years, for the sole purpose of infusing life into an inanimate body.
author: MWS

text: For this I had deprived myself of rest and health.
author: MWS

text: I had desired it with an ardour that far exceeded moderation; but now that I had finished, the beauty of the dream vanished, and breathless horror and disgust filled my heart.
author: MWS

text: Unable to endure the aspect of the being I had created, I rushed out of the room and continued a long time traversing my bed-chamber, unable to compose my mind to sleep.
author: MWS

text: At length lassitude succeeded to the tumult I had before endured, and I threw myself on the bed in my clothes, endeavouring to seek a few moments of forgetfulness.
author: MWS

text: But it was in vain; I slept, indeed, but I was disturbed by the wildest dreams.
author: MWS

text: I thought I saw Elizabeth, in the bloom of health, walking in the streets of Ingolstadt.
author: MWS

text: Delighted and surprised, I embraced her, but as I imprinted the first kiss on her lips, they became livid with the hue of death; her features appeared to change, and I thought that I held the corpse of my dead mother in my arms; a shroud enveloped her form, and I saw the grave-worms crawling in the folds of the flannel.
author: MWS

text: I started from my sleep with horror; a cold dew covered my forehead, my teeth chattered, and every limb became convulsed; when, by the dim and yellow light of the moon, as it forced its way through the window shutters, I beheld the wretch—the miserable monster whom I had created.
author: MWS

text: He held up the curtain of the bed; and his eyes, if eyes they may be called, were fixed on me.
author: MWS

text: His jaws opened, and he muttered some inarticulate sounds, while a grin wrinkled his cheeks.
author: MWS

text: He might have spoken, but I did not hear; one hand was stretched out, seemingly to detain me, but I escaped and rushed downstairs.
author: MWS

text: I took refuge in the courtyard belonging to the house which I inhabited, where I remained during the rest of the night, walking up and down in the greatest agitation, listening attentively, catching and fearing each sound as if it were to announce the approach of the demoniacal corpse to which I had so miserably given life.
author: MWS

text: No mortal could support the horror of that countenance.
author: MWS

text: Morning, dismal and wet, at length dawned and discovered to my sleepless and aching eyes the church of Ingolstadt, its white steeple and clock, which indicated the sixth hour.
author: MWS

text: The porter opened the gates of the court, which had that night been my asylum, and I issued into the streets, pacing them with quick steps, as if I sought to avoid the wretch whom I feared every turning of the street would present to my view.
author: MWS

text: I did not dare return to the apartment which I inhabited, but felt impelled to hurry on, although drenched by the rain which poured from a black and comfortless sky.
author: MWS

text: I continued walking in this manner for some time, endeavouring by bodily exercise to ease the load that weighed upon my mind.
author: MWS

text: I traversed the streets without any clear conception of where I was or what I was doing.
author: MWS

text: My heart palpitated in the sickness of fear, and I hurried on with irregular steps, not daring to look about me:      Like one who, on a lonely road,   Doth walk in fear and dread,   And, having once turned round, walks on,   And turns no more his head;   Because he knows a frightful fiend   Doth close behind him tread.
author: MWS

text: [Coleridge’s “Ancient Mariner.”]    Continuing thus, I came at length opposite to the inn at which the various diligences and carriages usually stopped.
author: MWS

text: Here I paused, I knew not why; but I remained some minutes with my eyes fixed on a coach that was coming towards me from the other end of the street.
author: MWS

text: As it drew nearer I observed that it was the Swiss diligence; it stopped just where I was standing, and on the door being opened, I perceived Henry Clerval, who, on seeing me, instantly sprung out.
author: MWS

text: “My dear Frankenstein,” exclaimed he, “how glad I am to see you!
author: MWS

text: How fortunate that you should be here at the very moment of my alighting!”  Nothing could equal my delight on seeing Clerval; his presence brought back to my thoughts my father, Elizabeth, and all those scenes of home so dear to my recollection.
author: MWS

text: I grasped his hand, and in a moment forgot my horror and misfortune; I felt suddenly, and for the first time during many months, calm and serene joy.
author: MWS

text: I welcomed my friend, therefore, in the most cordial manner, and we walked towards my college.
author: MWS

text: Clerval continued talking for some time about our mutual friends and his own good fortune in being permitted to come to Ingolstadt.
author: MWS

text: “You may easily believe,” said he, “how great was the difficulty to persuade my father that all necessary knowledge was not comprised in the noble art of book-keeping; and, indeed, I believe I left him incredulous to the last, for his constant answer to my unwearied entreaties was the same as that of the Dutch schoolmaster in The Vicar of Wakefield: ‘I have ten thousand florins a year without Greek, I eat heartily without Greek.’ But his affection for me at length overcame his dislike of learning, and he has permitted me to undertake a voyage of discovery to the land of knowledge.”  “It gives me the greatest delight to see you; but tell me how you left my father, brothers, and Elizabeth.”  “Very well, and very happy, only a little uneasy that they hear from you so seldom.
author: MWS

text: By the by, I mean to lecture you a little upon their account myself.
author: MWS

text: But, my dear Frankenstein,” continued he, stopping short and gazing full in my face, “I did not before remark how very ill you appear; so thin and pale; you look as if you had been watching for several nights.”  “You have guessed right; I have lately been so deeply engaged in one occupation that I have not allowed myself sufficient rest, as you see; but I hope, I sincerely hope, that all these employments are now at an end and that I am at length free.”  I trembled excessively; I could not endure to think of, and far less to allude to, the occurrences of the preceding night.

text: Doubtless my words surprised Henry; he at first believed them to be the wanderings of my disturbed imagination, but the pertinacity with which I continually recurred to the same subject persuaded him that my disorder indeed owed its origin to some uncommon and terrible event.

text: By very slow degrees, and with frequent relapses that alarmed and grieved my friend, I recovered.

text: I remember the first time I became capable of observing outward objects with any kind of pleasure, I perceived that the fallen leaves had disappeared and that the young buds were shooting forth from the trees that shaded my window.

author: MWS

text: “Dearest Clerval,” exclaimed I, “how kind, how very good you are to me.

text: It was from my own Elizabeth:  “My dearest Cousin,  “You have been ill, very ill, and even the constant letters of dear kind Henry are not sufficient to reassure me on your account.

text: I figure to myself that the task of attending on your sickbed has devolved on some mercenary old nurse, who could never guess your wishes nor minister to them with the care and affection of your poor cousin.

author: MWS

text: Your father’s health is vigorous, and he asks but to see you, but to be assured that you are well; and not a care will ever cloud his benevolent countenance.

text: “Little alteration, except the growth of our dear children, has taken place since you left us.

text: Since you left us, but one change has taken place in our little household.

My aunt observed this, and when Justine was twelve years of age, prevailed on her mother to allow her to live at our house.

text: The republican institutions of our country have produced simpler and happier manners than those which prevail in the great monarchies that surround it.

author: MWS

text: My aunt conceived a great attachment for her, by which she was induced to give her an education superior to that which she had at first intended.
author: MWS

text: This benefit was fully repaid; Justine was the most grateful little creature in the world:  I do not mean that she made any professions I never heard one pass her lips, but you could see by her eyes that she almost adored her protectress.
author: MWS

text: Although her disposition was gay and in many respects inconsiderate, yet she paid the greatest attention to every gesture of my aunt.
author: MWS

text: She thought her the model of all excellence and endeavoured to imitate her phraseology and manners, so that even now she often reminds me of her.
author: MWS

text: “When my dearest aunt died every one was too much occupied in their own grief to notice poor Justine, who had attended her during her illness with the most anxious affection.
author: MWS

text: “One by one, her brothers and sister died; and her mother, with the exception of her neglected daughter, was left childless.

author: MWS

text: We passed a fortnight in these perambulations:  my health and spirits had long been restored, and they gained additional strength from the salubrious air I breathed, the natural incidents of our progress, and the conversation of my friend.
author: MWS

text: Study had before secluded me from the intercourse of my fellow-creatures, and rendered me unsocial; but Clerval called forth the better feelings of my heart; he again taught me to love the aspect of nature, and the cheerful faces of children.

text: Chapter 7  On my return, I found the following letter from my father:—  “My dear Victor,  “You have probably waited impatiently for a letter to fix the date of your return to us; and I was at first tempted to write only a few lines, merely mentioning the day on which I should expect you.
author: MWS

text: But that would be a cruel kindness, and I dare not do it.
author: MWS

text: What would be your surprise, my son, when you expected a happy and glad welcome, to behold, on the contrary, tears and wretchedness?
author: MWS

text: And how, Victor, can I relate our misfortune?
author: MWS

text: Absence cannot have rendered you callous to our joys and griefs; and how shall I inflict pain on my long absent son?
author: MWS

text: I wish to prepare you for the woeful news, but I know it is impossible; even now your eye skims over the page to seek the words which are to convey to you the horrible tidings.
author: MWS

text: “William is dead!—that sweet child, whose smiles delighted and warmed my heart, who was so gentle, yet so gay!
author: MWS

text: Victor, he is murdered!

text: “I will not attempt to console you; but will simply relate the circumstances of the transaction.
author: MWS

text: “Last Thursday (May 7th), I, my niece, and your two brothers, went to walk in Plainpalais.

text: The evening was warm and serene, and we prolonged our walk farther than usual.

text: Her mild eyes seemed incapable of any severity or guile, and yet she has committed a murder.”  Soon after we heard that the poor victim had expressed a desire to see my cousin.
author: MWS

text: My father wished her not to go but said that he left it to her own judgment and feelings to decide.
author: MWS

text: “Yes,” said Elizabeth, “I will go, although she is guilty; and you, Victor, shall accompany me; I cannot go alone.” The idea of this visit was torture to me, yet I could not refuse.
author: MWS

text: We entered the gloomy prison chamber and beheld Justine sitting on some straw at the farther end; her hands were manacled, and her head rested on her knees.
author: MWS

text: She rose on seeing us enter, and when we were left alone with her, she threw herself at the feet of Elizabeth, weeping bitterly.
author: MWS

text: My cousin wept also.
author: MWS

text: “Oh, Justine!” said she.
author: MWS

text: “Why did you rob me of my last consolation?
author: MWS

text: I relied on your innocence, and although I was then very wretched, I was not so miserable as I am now.”  “And do you also believe that I am so very, very wicked?
author: MWS

text: Do you also join with my enemies to crush me, to condemn me as a murderer?” Her voice was suffocated with sobs.
author: MWS

text: “Rise, my poor girl,” said Elizabeth; “why do you kneel, if you are innocent?
author: MWS

text: I am not one of your enemies, I believed you guiltless, notwithstanding every evidence, until I heard that you had yourself declared your guilt.
author: MWS

text: That report, you say, is false; and be assured, dear Justine, that nothing can shake my confidence in you for a moment, but your own confession.”  “I did confess, but I confessed a lie.
author: MWS

text: I confessed, that I might obtain absolution; but now that falsehood lies heavier at my heart than all my other sins.
author: MWS

text: The God of heaven forgive me!
author: MWS

text: Ever since I was condemned, my confessor has besieged me; he threatened and menaced, until I almost began to think that I was the monster that he said I was.
author: MWS

text: He threatened excommunication and hell fire in my last moments if I continued obdurate.
author: MWS

text: Dear lady, I had none to support me; all looked on me as a wretch doomed to ignominy and perdition.
author: MWS

text: What could I do?
author: MWS

text: In an evil hour I subscribed to a lie; and now only am I truly miserable.”  She paused, weeping, and then continued, “I thought with horror, my sweet lady, that you should believe your Justine, whom your blessed aunt had so highly honoured, and whom you loved, was a creature capable of a crime which none but the devil himself could have perpetrated.
author: MWS

text: I soon shall see you again in heaven, where we shall all be happy; and that consoles me, going as I am to suffer ignominy and death.”  “Oh, Justine!
author: MWS

text: Forgive me for having for one moment distrusted you.
author: MWS

text: Why did you confess?
author: MWS

text: But do not mourn, dear girl.
author: MWS

text: I will proclaim, I will prove your innocence.
author: MWS

text: I will melt the stony hearts of your enemies by my tears and prayers.
author: MWS

text: You shall not die!
author: MWS

text: You, my playfellow, my companion, my sister, perish on the scaffold!
author: MWS

text: I never could survive so horrible a misfortune.”  Justine shook her head mournfully.
author: MWS

text: “I do not fear to die,” she said; “that pang is past.
author: MWS

text: God raises my weakness and gives me courage to endure the worst.
author: MWS

text: I leave a sad and bitter world; and if you remember me and think of me as of one unjustly condemned, I am resigned to the fate awaiting me.
author: MWS

text: Learn from me, dear lady, to submit in patience to the will of heaven!”  During this conversation I had retired to a corner of the prison room, where I could conceal the horrid anguish that possessed me.
author: MWS

text: Who dared talk of that?
author: MWS

text: The poor victim, who on the morrow was to pass the awful boundary between life and death, felt not, as I did, such deep and bitter agony.
author: MWS

text: I gnashed my teeth and ground them together, uttering a groan that came from my inmost soul.
author: MWS

text: When she saw who it was, she approached me and said, “Dear sir, you are very kind to visit me; you, I hope, do not believe that I am guilty?”  I could not answer.
author: MWS

text: “No, Justine,” said Elizabeth; “he is more convinced of your innocence than I was, for even when he heard that you had confessed, he did not credit it.”  “I truly thank him.
author: MWS

text: In these last moments I feel the sincerest gratitude towards those who think of me with kindness.
author: MWS

text: How sweet is the affection of others to such a wretch as I am!
author: MWS

text: It removes more than half my misfortune, and I feel as if I could die in peace now that my innocence is acknowledged by you, dear lady, and your cousin.”  Thus the poor sufferer tried to comfort others and herself.
author: MWS

text: She indeed gained the resignation she desired.
author: MWS

text: But I, the true murderer, felt the never-dying worm alive in my bosom, which allowed of no hope or consolation.
author: MWS

text: Elizabeth also wept and was unhappy, but hers also was the misery of innocence, which, like a cloud that passes over the fair moon, for a while hides but cannot tarnish its brightness.
author: MWS

text: Anguish and despair had penetrated into the core of my heart; I bore a hell within me which nothing could extinguish.
author: MWS

text: We stayed several hours with Justine, and it was with great difficulty that Elizabeth could tear herself away.
author: MWS

text: “I wish,” cried she, “that I were to die with you; I cannot live in this world of misery.”  Justine assumed an air of cheerfulness, while she with difficulty repressed her bitter tears.
author: MWS

text: She embraced Elizabeth and said in a voice of half-suppressed emotion, “Farewell, sweet lady, dearest Elizabeth, my beloved and only friend; may heaven, in its bounty, bless and preserve you; may this be the last misfortune that you will ever suffer!
author: MWS

text: Live, and be happy, and make others so.”  And on the morrow Justine died.
author: MWS

text: Elizabeth’s heart-rending eloquence failed to move the judges from their settled conviction in the criminality of the saintly sufferer.
author: MWS

text: My passionate and indignant appeals were lost upon them.
author: MWS

text: And when I received their cold answers and heard the harsh, unfeeling reasoning of these men, my purposed avowal died away on my lips.
author: MWS

text: Thus I might proclaim myself a madman, but not revoke the sentence passed upon my wretched victim.
author: MWS

text: She perished on the scaffold as a murderess!
author: MWS

text: From the tortures of my own heart, I turned to contemplate the deep and voiceless grief of my Elizabeth.
author: MWS

text: This also was my doing!
author: MWS

text: And my father’s woe, and the desolation of that late so smiling home all was the work of my thrice-accursed hands!
author: MWS

text: Ye weep, unhappy ones, but these are not your last tears!
author: MWS

text: Again shall you raise the funeral wail, and the sound of your lamentations shall again and again be heard!
author: MWS

text: Frankenstein, your son, your kinsman, your early, much-loved friend; he who would spend each vital drop of blood for your sakes, who has no thought nor sense of joy except as it is mirrored also in your dear countenances, who would fill the air with blessings and spend his life in serving you—he bids you weep, to shed countless tears; happy beyond his hopes, if thus inexorable fate be satisfied, and if the destruction pause before the peace of the grave have succeeded to your sad torments!
author: MWS

text: Thus spoke my prophetic soul, as, torn by remorse, horror, and despair, I beheld those I loved spend vain sorrow upon the graves of William and Justine, the first hapless victims to my unhallowed arts.
author: MWS

text: Chapter 9  Nothing is more painful to the human mind than, after the feelings have been worked up by a quick succession of events, the dead calmness of inaction and certainty which follows and deprives the soul both of hope and fear.
author: MWS

text: Justine died, she rested, and I was alive.
author: MWS

text: The blood flowed freely in my veins, but a weight of despair and remorse pressed on my heart which nothing could remove.
author: MWS

text: Sleep fled from my eyes; I wandered like an evil spirit, for I had committed deeds of mischief beyond description horrible, and more, much more (I persuaded myself) was yet behind.
author: MWS

text: Yet my heart overflowed with kindness and the love of virtue.
author: MWS

text: I had begun life with benevolent intentions and thirsted for the moment when I should put them in practice and make myself useful to my fellow beings.
author: MWS

text: Now all was blasted; instead of that serenity of conscience which allowed me to look back upon the past with self-satisfaction, and from thence to gather promise of new hopes, I was seized by remorse and the sense of guilt, which hurried me away to a hell of intense tortures such as no language can describe.
author: MWS

text: This state of mind preyed upon my health, which had perhaps never entirely recovered from the first shock it had sustained.
author: MWS

text: I shunned the face of man; all sound of joy or complacency was torture to me; solitude was my only consolation—deep, dark, deathlike solitude.
author: MWS

text: My father observed with pain the alteration perceptible in my disposition and habits and endeavoured by arguments deduced from the feelings of his serene conscience and guiltless life to inspire me with fortitude and awaken in me the courage to dispel the dark cloud which brooded over me.
author: MWS

text: “Do you think, Victor,” said he, “that I do not suffer also?
author: MWS

text: No one could love a child more than I loved your brother”—tears came into his eyes as he spoke—“but is it not a duty to the survivors that we should refrain from augmenting their unhappiness by an appearance of immoderate grief?
author: MWS

text: It is also a duty owed to yourself, for excessive sorrow prevents improvement or enjoyment, or even the discharge of daily usefulness, without which no man is fit for society.”  This advice, although good, was totally inapplicable to my case; I should have been the first to hide my grief and console my friends if remorse had not mingled its bitterness, and terror its alarm, with my other sensations.
author: MWS

text: Now I could only answer my father with a look of despair and endeavour to hide myself from his view.
author: MWS

text: About this time we retired to our house at Belrive.
author: MWS

text: This change was particularly agreeable to me.
author: MWS

text: The shutting of the gates regularly at ten o’clock and the impossibility of remaining on the lake after that hour had rendered our residence within the walls of Geneva very irksome to me.
author: MWS

text: I was now free.
author: MWS

text: Often, after the rest of the family had retired for the night, I took the boat and passed many hours upon the water.
author: MWS

text: Sometimes, with my sails set, I was carried by the wind; and sometimes, after rowing into the middle of the lake, I left the boat to pursue its own course and gave way to my own miserable reflections.
author: MWS

text: I was often tempted, when all was at peace around me, and I the only unquiet thing that wandered restless in a scene so beautiful and heavenly—if I except some bat, or the frogs, whose harsh and interrupted croaking was heard only when I approached the shore—often, I say, I was tempted to plunge into the silent lake, that the waters might close over me and my calamities for ever.
author: MWS

text: But I was restrained, when I thought of the heroic and suffering Elizabeth, whom I tenderly loved, and whose existence was bound up in mine.
author: MWS

text: I thought also of my father and surviving brother; should I by my base desertion leave them exposed and unprotected to the malice of the fiend whom I had let loose among them?
author: MWS

text: At these moments I wept bitterly and wished that peace would revisit my mind only that I might afford them consolation and happiness.
author: MWS

text: But that could not be.
author: MWS

text: Remorse extinguished every hope.
author: MWS

text: I had been the author of unalterable evils, and I lived in daily fear lest the monster whom I had created should perpetrate some new wickedness.
author: MWS

text: I had an obscure feeling that all was not over and that he would still commit some signal crime, which by its enormity should almost efface the recollection of the past.
author: MWS

text: There was always scope for fear so long as anything I loved remained behind.
author: MWS

text: My abhorrence of this fiend cannot be conceived.
author: MWS

text: When I thought of him I gnashed my teeth, my eyes became inflamed, and I ardently wished to extinguish that life which I had so thoughtlessly bestowed.
author: MWS

text: When I reflected on his crimes and malice, my hatred and revenge burst all bounds of moderation.
author: MWS

text: I would have made a pilgrimage to the highest peak of the Andes, could I, when there, have precipitated him to their base.
author: MWS

text: I wished to see him again, that I might wreak the utmost extent of abhorrence on his head and avenge the deaths of William and Justine.
author: MWS

text: Our house was the house of mourning.
author: MWS

text: My father’s health was deeply shaken by the horror of the recent events.
author: MWS

text: Elizabeth was sad and desponding; she no longer took delight in her ordinary occupations; all pleasure seemed to her sacrilege toward the dead; eternal woe and tears she then thought was the just tribute she should pay to innocence so blasted and destroyed.
author: MWS

text: She was no longer that happy creature who in earlier youth wandered with me on the banks of the lake and talked with ecstasy of our future prospects.
author: MWS

text: The first of those sorrows which are sent to wean us from the earth had visited her, and its dimming influence quenched her dearest smiles.
author: MWS

text: “When I reflect, my dear cousin,” said she, “on the miserable death of Justine Moritz, I no longer see the world and its works as they before appeared to me.
author: MWS

text: Before, I looked upon the accounts of vice and injustice that I read in books or heard from others as tales of ancient days or imaginary evils; at least they were remote and more familiar to reason than to the imagination; but now misery has come home, and men appear to me as monsters thirsting for each other’s blood.
author: MWS

text: Yet I am certainly unjust.
author: MWS

text: Everybody believed that poor girl to be guilty; and if she could have committed the crime for which she suffered, assuredly she would have been the most depraved of human creatures.
author: MWS

text: For the sake of a few jewels, to have murdered the son of her benefactor and friend, a child whom she had nursed from its birth, and appeared to love as if it had been her own!
author: MWS

text: I could not consent to the death of any human being, but certainly I should have thought such a creature unfit to remain in the society of men.
author: MWS

text: But she was innocent.
author: MWS

text: I know, I feel she was innocent; you are of the same opinion, and that confirms me.
author: MWS

text: Victor, when falsehood can look so like the truth, who can assure themselves of certain happiness?
author: MWS

text: I feel as if I were walking on the edge of a precipice, towards which thousands are crowding and endeavouring to plunge me into the abyss.
author: MWS

text: William and Justine were assassinated, and the murderer escapes; he walks about the world free, and perhaps respected.
author: MWS

text: But even if I were condemned to suffer on the scaffold for the same crimes, I would not change places with such a wretch.”  I listened to this discourse with the extremest agony.
author: MWS

text: I, not in deed, but in effect, was the true murderer.
author: MWS

text: Elizabeth read my anguish in my countenance, and kindly taking my hand, said, “My dearest friend, you must calm yourself.
author: MWS

text: These events have affected me, God knows how deeply; but I am not so wretched as you are.
author: MWS

text: There is an expression of despair, and sometimes of revenge, in your countenance that makes me tremble.
author: MWS

text: Dear Victor, banish these dark passions.
author: MWS

text: Remember the friends around you, who centre all their hopes in you.
author: MWS

text: Have we lost the power of rendering you happy?
author: MWS

text: While we love, while we are true to each other, here in this land of peace and beauty, your native country, we may reap every tranquil blessing—what can disturb our peace?”  And could not such words from her whom I fondly prized before every other gift of fortune suffice to chase away the fiend that lurked in my heart?
author: MWS

text: Even as she spoke I drew near to her, as if in terror, lest at that very moment the destroyer had been near to rob me of her.
author: MWS

text: Thus not the tenderness of friendship, nor the beauty of earth, nor of heaven, could redeem my soul from woe; the very accents of love were ineffectual.
author: MWS

text: I was encompassed by a cloud which no beneficial influence could penetrate.
author: MWS

text: The wounded deer dragging its fainting limbs to some untrodden brake, there to gaze upon the arrow which had pierced it, and to die, was but a type of me.
author: MWS

text: Sometimes I could cope with the sullen despair that overwhelmed me, but sometimes the whirlwind passions of my soul drove me to seek, by bodily exercise and by change of place, some relief from my intolerable sensations.
author: MWS

text: It was during an access of this kind that I suddenly left my home, and bending my steps towards the near Alpine valleys, sought in the magnificence, the eternity of such scenes, to forget myself and my ephemeral, because human, sorrows.
author: MWS

text: My wanderings were directed towards the valley of Chamounix.
author: MWS

text: I had visited it frequently during my boyhood.
author: MWS

text: Six years had passed since then: _I_ was a wreck, but nought had changed in those savage and enduring scenes.
author: MWS

text: I performed the first part of my journey on horseback.
author: MWS

text: I afterwards hired a mule, as the more sure-footed and least liable to receive injury on these rugged roads.
author: MWS

text: The weather was fine; it was about the middle of the month of August, nearly two months after the death of Justine, that miserable epoch from which I dated all my woe.
author: MWS

text: The weight upon my spirit was sensibly lightened as I plunged yet deeper in the ravine of Arve.
author: MWS

text: The immense mountains and precipices that overhung me on every side, the sound of the river raging among the rocks, and the dashing of the waterfalls around spoke of a power mighty as Omnipotence—and I ceased to fear or to bend before any being less almighty than that which had created and ruled the elements, here displayed in their most terrific guise.
author: MWS

text: Still, as I ascended higher, the valley assumed a more magnificent and astonishing character.
author: MWS

text: Ruined castles hanging on the precipices of piny mountains, the impetuous Arve, and cottages every here and there peeping forth from among the trees formed a scene of singular beauty.
author: MWS

text: But it was augmented and rendered sublime by the mighty Alps, whose white and shining pyramids and domes towered above all, as belonging to another earth, the habitations of another race of beings.
author: MWS

text: I passed the bridge of Pélissier, where the ravine, which the river forms, opened before me, and I began to ascend the mountain that overhangs it.
author: MWS

text: Soon after, I entered the valley of Chamounix.
author: MWS

text: This valley is more wonderful and sublime, but not so beautiful and picturesque as that of Servox, through which I had just passed.
author: MWS

text: The high and snowy mountains were its immediate boundaries, but I saw no more ruined castles and fertile fields.
author: MWS

text: Immense glaciers approached the road; I heard the rumbling thunder of the falling avalanche and marked the smoke of its passage.
author: MWS

text: Mont Blanc, the supreme and magnificent Mont Blanc, raised itself from the surrounding _aiguilles_, and its tremendous _dôme_ overlooked the valley.
author: MWS

text: A tingling long-lost sense of pleasure often came across me during this journey.
author: MWS

text: Some turn in the road, some new object suddenly perceived and recognised, reminded me of days gone by, and were associated with the lighthearted gaiety of boyhood.
author: MWS

text: The very winds whispered in soothing accents, and maternal Nature bade me weep no more.
author: MWS

text: Then again the kindly influence ceased to act—I found myself fettered again to grief and indulging in all the misery of reflection.
author: MWS

text: Then I spurred on my animal, striving so to forget the world, my fears, and more than all, myself—or, in a more desperate fashion, I alighted and threw myself on the grass, weighed down by horror and despair.
author: MWS

text: At length I arrived at the village of Chamounix.
author: MWS

text: Exhaustion succeeded to the extreme fatigue both of body and of mind which I had endured.
author: MWS

text: For a short space of time I remained at the window watching the pallid lightnings that played above Mont Blanc and listening to the rushing of the Arve, which pursued its noisy way beneath.
author: MWS

text: The same lulling sounds acted as a lullaby to my too keen sensations; when I placed my head upon my pillow, sleep crept over me; I felt it as it came and blessed the giver of oblivion.
author: MWS

text: Chapter 10  I spent the following day roaming through the valley.
author: MWS

text: I stood beside the sources of the Arveiron, which take their rise in a glacier, that with slow pace is advancing down from the summit of the hills to barricade the valley.
author: MWS

text: The abrupt sides of vast mountains were before me; the icy wall of the glacier overhung me; a few shattered pines were scattered around; and the solemn silence of this glorious presence-chamber of imperial Nature was broken only by the brawling waves or the fall of some vast fragment, the thunder sound of the avalanche or the cracking, reverberated along the mountains, of the accumulated ice, which, through the silent working of immutable laws, was ever and anon rent and torn, as if it had been but a plaything in their hands.
author: MWS

text: These sublime and magnificent scenes afforded me the greatest consolation that I was capable of receiving.
author: MWS

text: They elevated me from all littleness of feeling, and although they did not remove my grief, they subdued and tranquillised it.
author: MWS

text: In some degree, also, they diverted my mind from the thoughts over which it had brooded for the last month.
author: MWS

text: I retired to rest at night; my slumbers, as it were, waited on and ministered to by the assemblance of grand shapes which I had contemplated during the day.
author: MWS

text: They congregated round me; the unstained snowy mountain-top, the glittering pinnacle, the pine woods, and ragged bare ravine, the eagle, soaring amidst the clouds—they all gathered round me and bade me be at peace.
author: MWS

text: Where had they fled when the next morning I awoke?
author: MWS

text: All of soul-inspiriting fled with sleep, and dark melancholy clouded every thought.
author: MWS

text: The rain was pouring in torrents, and thick mists hid the summits of the mountains, so that I even saw not the faces of those mighty friends.
author: MWS

text: Still I would penetrate their misty veil and seek them in their cloudy retreats.
author: MWS

text: What were rain and storm to me?
author: MWS

text: My mule was brought to the door, and I resolved to ascend to the summit of Montanvert.
author: MWS

text: I remembered the effect that the view of the tremendous and ever-moving glacier had produced upon my mind when I first saw it.
author: MWS

text: It had then filled me with a sublime ecstasy that gave wings to the soul and allowed it to soar from the obscure world to light and joy.
author: MWS

text: The sight of the awful and majestic in nature had indeed always the effect of solemnising my mind and causing me to forget the passing cares of life.
author: MWS

text: I determined to go without a guide, for I was well acquainted with the path, and the presence of another would destroy the solitary grandeur of the scene.
author: MWS

text: The ascent is precipitous, but the path is cut into continual and short windings, which enable you to surmount the perpendicularity of the mountain.
author: MWS

text: It is a scene terrifically desolate.
author: MWS

text: In a thousand spots the traces of the winter avalanche may be perceived, where trees lie broken and strewed on the ground, some entirely destroyed, others bent, leaning upon the jutting rocks of the mountain or transversely upon other trees.
author: MWS

text: The path, as you ascend higher, is intersected by ravines of snow, down which stones continually roll from above; one of them is particularly dangerous, as the slightest sound, such as even speaking in a loud voice, produces a concussion of air sufficient to draw destruction upon the head of the speaker.
author: MWS

text: The pines are not tall or luxuriant, but they are sombre and add an air of severity to the scene.
author: MWS

text: I looked on the valley beneath; vast mists were rising from the rivers which ran through it and curling in thick wreaths around the opposite mountains, whose summits were hid in the uniform clouds, while rain poured from the dark sky and added to the melancholy impression I received from the objects around me.
author: MWS

text: Why does man boast of sensibilities superior to those apparent in the brute; it only renders them more necessary beings.
author: MWS

text: If our impulses were confined to hunger, thirst, and desire, we might be nearly free; but now we are moved by every wind that blows and a chance word or scene that that word may convey to us.
author: MWS

text: We rest; a dream has power to poison sleep.
author: MWS

text: We rise; one wand’ring thought pollutes the day.
author: MWS

text: We feel, conceive, or reason; laugh or weep,        Embrace fond woe, or cast our cares away;   It is the same:  for, be it joy or sorrow,        The path of its departure still is free.
author: MWS

text: Man’s yesterday may ne’er be like his morrow;        Nought may endure but mutability!
author: MWS

text: It was nearly noon when I arrived at the top of the ascent.
author: MWS

text: For some time I sat upon the rock that overlooks the sea of ice.
author: MWS

text: A mist covered both that and the surrounding mountains.
author: MWS

text: Presently a breeze dissipated the cloud, and I descended upon the glacier.
author: MWS

text: The surface is very uneven, rising like the waves of a troubled sea, descending low, and interspersed by rifts that sink deep.
author: MWS

text: The field of ice is almost a league in width, but I spent nearly two hours in crossing it.
author: MWS

text: The opposite mountain is a bare perpendicular rock.
author: MWS

text: From the side where I now stood Montanvert was exactly opposite, at the distance of a league; and above it rose Mont Blanc, in awful majesty.
author: MWS

text: I remained in a recess of the rock, gazing on this wonderful and stupendous scene.
author: MWS

text: The sea, or rather the vast river of ice, wound among its dependent mountains, whose aerial summits hung over its recesses.
author: MWS

text: Their icy and glittering peaks shone in the sunlight over the clouds.
author: MWS

text: My heart, which was before sorrowful, now swelled with something like joy; I exclaimed, “Wandering spirits, if indeed ye wander, and do not rest in your narrow beds, allow me this faint happiness, or take me, as your companion, away from the joys of life.”  As I said this I suddenly beheld the figure of a man, at some distance, advancing towards me with superhuman speed.
author: MWS

text: He bounded over the crevices in the ice, among which I had walked with caution; his stature, also, as he approached, seemed to exceed that of man.
author: MWS

text: I was troubled; a mist came over my eyes, and I felt a faintness seize me, but I was quickly restored by the cold gale of the mountains.
author: MWS

text: I perceived, as the shape came nearer (sight tremendous and abhorred!)
author: MWS

text: that it was the wretch whom I had created.
author: MWS

text: I trembled with rage and horror, resolving to wait his approach and then close with him in mortal combat.
author: MWS

text: He approached; his countenance bespoke bitter anguish, combined with disdain and malignity, while its unearthly ugliness rendered it almost too horrible for human eyes.
author: MWS

text: But I scarcely observed this; rage and hatred had at first deprived me of utterance, and I recovered only to overwhelm him with words expressive of furious detestation and contempt.
author: MWS

text: “Devil,” I exclaimed, “do you dare approach me?
author: MWS

text: And do not you fear the fierce vengeance of my arm wreaked on your miserable head?
author: MWS

text: Or rather, stay, that I may trample you to dust!
author: MWS

text: That I could, with the extinction of your miserable existence, restore those victims whom you have so diabolically murdered!”  “I expected this reception,” said the dæmon.
author: MWS

text: “All men hate the wretched; how, then, must I be hated, who am miserable beyond all living things!
author: MWS

text: Yet you, my creator, detest and spurn me, thy creature, to whom thou art bound by ties only dissoluble by the annihilation of one of us.
author: MWS

text: You purpose to kill me.
author: MWS

text: How dare you sport thus with life?
author: MWS

text: Do your duty towards me, and I will do mine towards you and the rest of mankind.
author: MWS

text: If you will comply with my conditions, I will leave them and you at peace; but if you refuse, I will glut the maw of death, until it be satiated with the blood of your remaining friends.”  “Abhorred monster!
author: MWS

text: Fiend that thou art!
author: MWS

text: The tortures of hell are too mild a vengeance for thy crimes.
author: MWS

text: You reproach me with your creation, come on, then, that I may extinguish the spark which I so negligently bestowed.”  My rage was without bounds; I sprang on him, impelled by all the feelings which can arm one being against the existence of another.
author: MWS

text: He easily eluded me and said,  “Be calm!
author: MWS

text: I entreat you to hear me before you give vent to your hatred on my devoted head.
author: MWS

text: Have I not suffered enough, that you seek to increase my misery?
author: MWS

text: Life, although it may only be an accumulation of anguish, is dear to me, and I will defend it.
author: MWS

text: Remember, thou hast made me more powerful than thyself; my height is superior to thine, my joints more supple.
author: MWS

text: But I will not be tempted to set myself in opposition to thee.
author: MWS

text: I am thy creature, and I will be even mild and docile to my natural lord and king if thou wilt also perform thy part, the which thou owest me.
author: MWS

text: Oh, Frankenstein, be not equitable to every other and trample upon me alone, to whom thy justice, and even thy clemency and affection, is most due.
author: MWS

text: Remember that I am thy creature; I ought to be thy Adam, but I am rather the fallen angel, whom thou drivest from joy for no misdeed.
author: MWS

text: Everywhere I see bliss, from which I alone am irrevocably excluded.
author: MWS

text: I was benevolent and good; misery made me a fiend.
author: MWS

text: Make me happy, and I shall again be virtuous.”  “Begone!
author: MWS

text: I will not hear you.
author: MWS

text: There can be no community between you and me; we are enemies.
author: MWS

text: Begone, or let us try our strength in a fight, in which one must fall.”  “How can I move thee?
author: MWS

text: Will no entreaties cause thee to turn a favourable eye upon thy creature, who implores thy goodness and compassion?
author: MWS

text: Believe me, Frankenstein, I was benevolent; my soul glowed with love and humanity; but am I not alone, miserably alone?
author: MWS

text: You, my creator, abhor me; what hope can I gather from your fellow creatures, who owe me nothing?
author: MWS

text: They spurn and hate me.
author: MWS

text: The desert mountains and dreary glaciers are my refuge.
author: MWS

text: I have wandered here many days; the caves of ice, which I only do not fear, are a dwelling to me, and the only one which man does not grudge.
author: MWS

text: These bleak skies I hail, for they are kinder to me than your fellow beings.
author: MWS

text: If the multitude of mankind knew of my existence, they would do as you do, and arm themselves for my destruction.
author: MWS

text: Shall I not then hate them who abhor me?
author: MWS

text: I will keep no terms with my enemies.
author: MWS

text: I am miserable, and they shall share my wretchedness.
author: MWS

text: Yet it is in your power to recompense me, and deliver them from an evil which it only remains for you to make so great, that not only you and your family, but thousands of others, shall be swallowed up in the whirlwinds of its rage.
author: MWS

text: Let your compassion be moved, and do not disdain me.
author: MWS

text: Listen to my tale; when you have heard that, abandon or commiserate me, as you shall judge that I deserve.
author: MWS

text: The guilty are allowed, by human laws, bloody as they are, to speak in their own defence before they are condemned.
author: MWS

text: Listen to me, Frankenstein.
author: MWS

text: You accuse me of murder, and yet you would, with a satisfied conscience, destroy your own creature.
author: MWS

text: Oh, praise the eternal justice of man!
author: MWS

text: Yet I ask you not to spare me; listen to me, and then, if you can, and if you will, destroy the work of your hands.”  “Why do you call to my remembrance,” I rejoined, “circumstances of which I shudder to reflect, that I have been the miserable origin and author?
author: MWS

text: Cursed be the day, abhorred devil, in which you first saw light!
author: MWS

text: Cursed (although I curse myself) be the hands that formed you!
author: MWS

text: You have made me wretched beyond expression.
author: MWS

text: You have left me no power to consider whether I am just to you or not.
author: MWS

text: Relieve me from the sight of your detested form.”  “Thus I relieve thee, my creator,” he said, and placed his hated hands before my eyes, which I flung from me with violence; “thus I take from thee a sight which you abhor.
author: MWS

text: Still thou canst listen to me and grant me thy compassion.
author: MWS

text: By the virtues that I once possessed, I demand this from you.
author: MWS

text: Hear my tale; it is long and strange, and the temperature of this place is not fitting to your fine sensations; come to the hut upon the mountain.
author: MWS

text: The sun is yet high in the heavens; before it descends to hide itself behind your snowy precipices and illuminate another world, you will have heard my story and can decide.
author: MWS

text: On you it rests, whether I quit for ever the neighbourhood of man and lead a harmless life, or become the scourge of your fellow creatures and the author of your own speedy ruin.”  As he said this he led the way across the ice; I followed.
author: MWS

text: My heart was full, and I did not answer him, but as I proceeded, I weighed the various arguments that he had used and determined at least to listen to his tale.
author: MWS

text: I was partly urged by curiosity, and compassion confirmed my resolution.
author: MWS

text: I had hitherto supposed him to be the murderer of my brother, and I eagerly sought a confirmation or denial of this opinion.
author: MWS

text: For the first time, also, I felt what the duties of a creator towards his creature were, and that I ought to render him happy before I complained of his wickedness.
author: MWS

text: These motives urged me to comply with his demand.
author: MWS

text: We crossed the ice, therefore, and ascended the opposite rock.
author: MWS

text: The air was cold, and the rain again began to descend; we entered the hut, the fiend with an air of exultation, I with a heavy heart and depressed spirits.
author: MWS

text: But I consented to listen, and seating myself by the fire which my odious companion had lighted, he thus began his tale.
author: MWS

text: Chapter 11  “It is with considerable difficulty that I remember the original era of my being; all the events of that period appear confused and indistinct.
author: MWS

text: A strange multiplicity of sensations seized me, and I saw, felt, heard, and smelt at the same time; and it was, indeed, a long time before I learned to distinguish between the operations of my various senses.
author: MWS

text: By degrees, I remember, a stronger light pressed upon my nerves, so that I was obliged to shut my eyes.
author: MWS

text: Darkness then came over me and troubled me, but hardly had I felt this when, by opening my eyes, as I now suppose, the light poured in upon me again.
author: MWS

text: I walked and, I believe, descended, but I presently found a great alteration in my sensations.
author: MWS

text: Before, dark and opaque bodies had surrounded me, impervious to my touch or sight; but I now found that I could wander on at liberty, with no obstacles which I could not either surmount or avoid.
author: MWS

text: The light became more and more oppressive to me, and the heat wearying me as I walked, I sought a place where I could receive shade.
author: MWS

text: This was the forest near Ingolstadt; and here I lay by the side of a brook resting from my fatigue, until I felt tormented by hunger and thirst.
author: MWS

text: This roused me from my nearly dormant state, and I ate some berries which I found hanging on the trees or lying on the ground.
author: MWS

text: I slaked my thirst at the brook, and then lying down, was overcome by sleep.
author: MWS

text: “It was dark when I awoke; I felt cold also, and half frightened, as it were, instinctively, finding myself so desolate.
author: MWS

text: Before I had quitted your apartment, on a sensation of cold, I had covered myself with some clothes, but these were insufficient to secure me from the dews of night.
author: MWS

text: I was a poor, helpless, miserable wretch; I knew, and could distinguish, nothing; but feeling pain invade me on all sides, I sat down and wept.
author: MWS

text: “Soon a gentle light stole over the heavens and gave me a sensation of pleasure.
author: MWS

text: I started up and beheld a radiant form rise from among the trees.
author: MWS

text: [The moon]  I gazed with a kind of wonder.
author: MWS

text: It moved slowly, but it enlightened my path, and I again went out in search of berries.
author: MWS

text: I was still cold when under one of the trees I found a huge cloak, with which I covered myself, and sat down upon the ground.
author: MWS

text: No distinct ideas occupied my mind; all was confused.
author: MWS

text: I felt light, and hunger, and thirst, and darkness; innumerable sounds rang in my ears, and on all sides various scents saluted me; the only object that I could distinguish was the bright moon, and I fixed my eyes on that with pleasure.
author: MWS

text: “Several changes of day and night passed, and the orb of night had greatly lessened, when I began to distinguish my sensations from each other.
author: MWS

text: I gradually saw plainly the clear stream that supplied me with drink and the trees that shaded me with their foliage.
author: MWS

text: I was delighted when I first discovered that a pleasant sound, which often saluted my ears, proceeded from the throats of the little winged animals who had often intercepted the light from my eyes.
author: MWS

text: I began also to observe, with greater accuracy, the forms that surrounded me and to perceive the boundaries of the radiant roof of light which canopied me.
author: MWS

text: Sometimes I tried to imitate the pleasant songs of the birds but was unable.
author: MWS

text: Sometimes I wished to express my sensations in my own mode, but the uncouth and inarticulate sounds which broke from me frightened me into silence again.
author: MWS

text: “The moon had disappeared from the night, and again, with a lessened form, showed itself, while I still remained in the forest.
author: MWS

text: My sensations had by this time become distinct, and my mind received every day additional ideas.
author: MWS

text: My eyes became accustomed to the light and to perceive objects in their right forms; I distinguished the insect from the herb, and by degrees, one herb from another.
author: MWS

text: I found that the sparrow uttered none but harsh notes, whilst those of the blackbird and thrush were sweet and enticing.
author: MWS

text: “One day, when I was oppressed by cold, I found a fire which had been left by some wandering beggars, and was overcome with delight at the warmth I experienced from it.
author: MWS

text: In my joy I thrust my hand into the live embers, but quickly drew it out again with a cry of pain.
author: MWS

text: How strange, I thought, that the same cause should produce such opposite effects!
author: MWS

text: I examined the materials of the fire, and to my joy found it to be composed of wood.
author: MWS

text: I quickly collected some branches, but they were wet and would not burn.
author: MWS

text: I was pained at this and sat still watching the operation of the fire.
author: MWS

text: The wet wood which I had placed near the heat dried and itself became inflamed.
author: MWS

text: I reflected on this, and by touching the various branches, I discovered the cause and busied myself in collecting a great quantity of wood, that I might dry it and have a plentiful supply of fire.
author: MWS

text: When night came on and brought sleep with it, I was in the greatest fear lest my fire should be extinguished.
author: MWS

text: I covered it carefully with dry wood and leaves and placed wet branches upon it; and then, spreading my cloak, I lay on the ground and sank into sleep.
author: MWS

text: “It was morning when I awoke, and my first care was to visit the fire.
author: MWS

text: I uncovered it, and a gentle breeze quickly fanned it into a flame.
author: MWS

text: I observed this also and contrived a fan of branches, which roused the embers when they were nearly extinguished.
author: MWS

text: When night came again I found, with pleasure, that the fire gave light as well as heat and that the discovery of this element was useful to me in my food, for I found some of the offals that the travellers had left had been roasted, and tasted much more savoury than the berries I gathered from the trees.
author: MWS

text: I tried, therefore, to dress my food in the same manner, placing it on the live embers.
author: MWS

text: I found that the berries were spoiled by this operation, and the nuts and roots much improved.
author: MWS

text: “Food, however, became scarce, and I often spent the whole day searching in vain for a few acorns to assuage the pangs of hunger.
author: MWS

text: When I found this, I resolved to quit the place that I had hitherto inhabited, to seek for one where the few wants I experienced would be more easily satisfied.
author: MWS

text: In this emigration I exceedingly lamented the loss of the fire which I had obtained through accident and knew not how to reproduce it.
author: MWS

text: I gave several hours to the serious consideration of this difficulty, but I was obliged to relinquish all attempt to supply it, and wrapping myself up in my cloak, I struck across the wood towards the setting sun.
author: MWS

text: I passed three days in these rambles and at length discovered the open country.
author: MWS

text: A great fall of snow had taken place the night before, and the fields were of one uniform white; the appearance was disconsolate, and I found my feet chilled by the cold damp substance that covered the ground.
author: MWS

text: “It was about seven in the morning, and I longed to obtain food and shelter; at length I perceived a small hut, on a rising ground, which had doubtless been built for the convenience of some shepherd.
author: MWS

text: This was a new sight to me, and I examined the structure with great curiosity.
author: MWS

text: Finding the door open, I entered.
author: MWS

text: An old man sat in it, near a fire, over which he was preparing his breakfast.
author: MWS

text: He turned on hearing a noise, and perceiving me, shrieked loudly, and quitting the hut, ran across the fields with a speed of which his debilitated form hardly appeared capable.
author: MWS

text: His appearance, different from any I had ever before seen, and his flight somewhat surprised me.
author: MWS

text: But I was enchanted by the appearance of the hut; here the snow and rain could not penetrate; the ground was dry; and it presented to me then as exquisite and divine a retreat as Pandæmonium appeared to the dæmons of hell after their sufferings in the lake of fire.
author: MWS

text: I greedily devoured the remnants of the shepherd’s breakfast, which consisted of bread, cheese, milk, and wine; the latter, however, I did not like.
author: MWS

text: Then, overcome by fatigue, I lay down among some straw and fell asleep.
author: MWS

text: “It was noon when I awoke, and allured by the warmth of the sun, which shone brightly on the white ground, I determined to recommence my travels; and, depositing the remains of the peasant’s breakfast in a wallet I found, I proceeded across the fields for several hours, until at sunset I arrived at a village.
author: MWS

text: How miraculous did this appear!
author: MWS

text: The huts, the neater cottages, and stately houses engaged my admiration by turns.
author: MWS

text: The vegetables in the gardens, the milk and cheese that I saw placed at the windows of some of the cottages, allured my appetite.
author: MWS

text: One of the best of these I entered, but I had hardly placed my foot within the door before the children shrieked, and one of the women fainted.
author: MWS

text: The whole village was roused; some fled, some attacked me, until, grievously bruised by stones and many other kinds of missile weapons, I escaped to the open country and fearfully took refuge in a low hovel, quite bare, and making a wretched appearance after the palaces I had beheld in the village.
author: MWS

text: This hovel however, joined a cottage of a neat and pleasant appearance, but after my late dearly bought experience, I dared not enter it.
author: MWS

text: My place of refuge was constructed of wood, but so low that I could with difficulty sit upright in it.
author: MWS

text: No wood, however, was placed on the earth, which formed the floor, but it was dry; and although the wind entered it by innumerable chinks, I found it an agreeable asylum from the snow and rain.
author: MWS

text: “Here, then, I retreated and lay down happy to have found a shelter, however miserable, from the inclemency of the season, and still more from the barbarity of man.
author: MWS

text: As soon as morning dawned I crept from my kennel, that I might view the adjacent cottage and discover if I could remain in the habitation I had found.
author: MWS

text: It was situated against the back of the cottage and surrounded on the sides which were exposed by a pig sty and a clear pool of water.
author: MWS

text: One part was open, and by that I had crept in; but now I covered every crevice by which I might be perceived with stones and wood, yet in such a manner that I might move them on occasion to pass out; all the light I enjoyed came through the sty, and that was sufficient for me.
author: MWS

text: “Having thus arranged my dwelling and carpeted it with clean straw, I retired, for I saw the figure of a man at a distance, and I remembered too well my treatment the night before to trust myself in his power.
author: MWS

text: I had first, however, provided for my sustenance for that day by a loaf of coarse bread, which I purloined, and a cup with which I could drink more conveniently than from my hand of the pure water which flowed by my retreat.
author: MWS

text: The floor was a little raised, so that it was kept perfectly dry, and by its vicinity to the chimney of the cottage it was tolerably warm.
author: MWS

text: “Being thus provided, I resolved to reside in this hovel until something should occur which might alter my determination.
author: MWS

text: It was indeed a paradise compared to the bleak forest, my former residence, the rain-dropping branches, and dank earth.
author: MWS

text: I ate my breakfast with pleasure and was about to remove a plank to procure myself a little water when I heard a step, and looking through a small chink, I beheld a young creature, with a pail on her head, passing before my hovel.
author: MWS

text: The girl was young and of gentle demeanour, unlike what I have since found cottagers and farmhouse servants to be.
author: MWS

text: Yet she was meanly dressed, a coarse blue petticoat and a linen jacket being her only garb; her fair hair was plaited but not adorned:  she looked patient yet sad.
author: MWS

text: I lost sight of her, and in about a quarter of an hour she returned bearing the pail, which was now partly filled with milk.
author: MWS

text: As she walked along, seemingly incommoded by the burden, a young man met her, whose countenance expressed a deeper despondence.
author: MWS

text: Uttering a few sounds with an air of melancholy, he took the pail from her head and bore it to the cottage himself.
author: MWS

text: She followed, and they disappeared.
author: MWS

text: Presently I saw the young man again, with some tools in his hand, cross the field behind the cottage; and the girl was also busied, sometimes in the house and sometimes in the yard.
author: MWS

text: “On examining my dwelling, I found that one of the windows of the cottage had formerly occupied a part of it, but the panes had been filled up with wood.
author: MWS

text: In one of these was a small and almost imperceptible chink through which the eye could just penetrate.
author: MWS

text: Through this crevice a small room was visible, whitewashed and clean but very bare of furniture.
author: MWS

text: In one corner, near a small fire, sat an old man, leaning his head on his hands in a disconsolate attitude.
author: MWS

text: The young girl was occupied in arranging the cottage; but presently she took something out of a drawer, which employed her hands, and she sat down beside the old man, who, taking up an instrument, began to play and to produce sounds sweeter than the voice of the thrush or the nightingale.
author: MWS

text: It was a lovely sight, even to me, poor wretch who had never beheld aught beautiful before.
author: MWS

text: The silver hair and benevolent countenance of the aged cottager won my reverence, while the gentle manners of the girl enticed my love.
author: MWS

text: He played a sweet mournful air which I perceived drew tears from the eyes of his amiable companion, of which the old man took no notice, until she sobbed audibly; he then pronounced a few sounds, and the fair creature, leaving her work, knelt at his feet.
author: MWS

text: He raised her and smiled with such kindness and affection that I felt sensations of a peculiar and overpowering nature; they were a mixture of pain and pleasure, such as I had never before experienced, either from hunger or cold, warmth or food; and I withdrew from the window, unable to bear these emotions.
author: MWS

text: “Soon after this the young man returned, bearing on his shoulders a load of wood.
author: MWS

text: The girl met him at the door, helped to relieve him of his burden, and taking some of the fuel into the cottage, placed it on the fire; then she and the youth went apart into a nook of the cottage, and he showed her a large loaf and a piece of cheese.
author: MWS

text: She seemed pleased and went into the garden for some roots and plants, which she placed in water, and then upon the fire.
author: MWS

text: She afterwards continued her work, whilst the young man went into the garden and appeared busily employed in digging and pulling up roots.
