author: MWS

text: After he had been employed thus about an hour, the young woman joined him and they entered the cottage together.
author: MWS

text: “The old man had, in the meantime, been pensive, but on the appearance of his companions he assumed a more cheerful air, and they sat down to eat.
author: MWS

text: The meal was quickly dispatched.
author: MWS

text: The young woman was again occupied in arranging the cottage, the old man walked before the cottage in the sun for a few minutes, leaning on the arm of the youth.
author: MWS

text: Nothing could exceed in beauty the contrast between these two excellent creatures.
author: MWS

text: One was old, with silver hairs and a countenance beaming with benevolence and love; the younger was slight and graceful in his figure, and his features were moulded with the finest symmetry, yet his eyes and attitude expressed the utmost sadness and despondency.
author: MWS

text: The old man returned to the cottage, and the youth, with tools different from those he had used in the morning, directed his steps across the fields.
author: MWS

text: “Night quickly shut in, but to my extreme wonder, I found that the cottagers had a means of prolonging light by the use of tapers, and was delighted to find that the setting of the sun did not put an end to the pleasure I experienced in watching my human neighbours.
author: MWS

text: In the evening the young girl and her companion were employed in various occupations which I did not understand; and the old man again took up the instrument which produced the divine sounds that had enchanted me in the morning.
author: MWS

text: So soon as he had finished, the youth began, not to play, but to utter sounds that were monotonous, and neither resembling the harmony of the old man’s instrument nor the songs of the birds; I since found that he read aloud, but at that time I knew nothing of the science of words or letters.
author: MWS

text: “The family, after having been thus occupied for a short time, extinguished their lights and retired, as I conjectured, to rest.”      Chapter 12  “I lay on my straw, but I could not sleep.
author: MWS

text: I thought of the occurrences of the day.
author: MWS

text: What chiefly struck me was the gentle manners of these people, and I longed to join them, but dared not.
author: MWS

text: I remembered too well the treatment I had suffered the night before from the barbarous villagers, and resolved, whatever course of conduct I might hereafter think it right to pursue, that for the present I would remain quietly in my hovel, watching and endeavouring to discover the motives which influenced their actions.
author: MWS

text: “The cottagers arose the next morning before the sun.
author: MWS

text: The young woman arranged the cottage and prepared the food, and the youth departed after the first meal.
author: MWS

text: “This day was passed in the same routine as that which preceded it.
author: MWS

text: The young man was constantly employed out of doors, and the girl in various laborious occupations within.
author: MWS

text: The old man, whom I soon perceived to be blind, employed his leisure hours on his instrument or in contemplation.
author: MWS

text: Nothing could exceed the love and respect which the younger cottagers exhibited towards their venerable companion.
author: MWS

text: They performed towards him every little office of affection and duty with gentleness, and he rewarded them by his benevolent smiles.
author: MWS

text: “They were not entirely happy.
author: MWS

text: The young man and his companion often went apart and appeared to weep.
author: MWS

text: I saw no cause for their unhappiness, but I was deeply affected by it.
author: MWS

text: If such lovely creatures were miserable, it was less strange that I, an imperfect and solitary being, should be wretched.
author: MWS

text: Yet why were these gentle beings unhappy?
author: MWS

text: They possessed a delightful house (for such it was in my eyes) and every luxury; they had a fire to warm them when chill and delicious viands when hungry; they were dressed in excellent clothes; and, still more, they enjoyed one another’s company and speech, interchanging each day looks of affection and kindness.
author: MWS

text: What did their tears imply?
author: MWS

text: Did they really express pain?
author: MWS

text: I was at first unable to solve these questions, but perpetual attention and time explained to me many appearances which were at first enigmatic.
author: MWS

text: “A considerable period elapsed before I discovered one of the causes of the uneasiness of this amiable family:  it was poverty, and they suffered that evil in a very distressing degree.
author: MWS

text: Their nourishment consisted entirely of the vegetables of their garden and the milk of one cow, which gave very little during the winter, when its masters could scarcely procure food to support it.
author: MWS

text: They often, I believe, suffered the pangs of hunger very poignantly, especially the two younger cottagers, for several times they placed food before the old man when they reserved none for themselves.
author: MWS

text: “This trait of kindness moved me sensibly.
author: MWS

text: I had been accustomed, during the night, to steal a part of their store for my own consumption, but when I found that in doing this I inflicted pain on the cottagers, I abstained and satisfied myself with berries, nuts, and roots which I gathered from a neighbouring wood.
author: MWS

text: “I discovered also another means through which I was enabled to assist their labours.
author: MWS

text: I found that the youth spent a great part of each day in collecting wood for the family fire, and during the night I often took his tools, the use of which I quickly discovered, and brought home firing sufficient for the consumption of several days.
author: MWS

text: “I remember, the first time that I did this, the young woman, when she opened the door in the morning, appeared greatly astonished on seeing a great pile of wood on the outside.
author: MWS

text: She uttered some words in a loud voice, and the youth joined her, who also expressed surprise.
author: MWS

text: I observed, with pleasure, that he did not go to the forest that day, but spent it in repairing the cottage and cultivating the garden.
author: MWS

text: “By degrees I made a discovery of still greater moment.
author: MWS

text: I found that these people possessed a method of communicating their experience and feelings to one another by articulate sounds.
author: MWS

text: I perceived that the words they spoke sometimes produced pleasure or pain, smiles or sadness, in the minds and countenances of the hearers.
author: MWS

text: This was indeed a godlike science, and I ardently desired to become acquainted with it.
author: MWS

text: But I was baffled in every attempt I made for this purpose.
author: MWS

text: Their pronunciation was quick, and the words they uttered, not having any apparent connection with visible objects, I was unable to discover any clue by which I could unravel the mystery of their reference.
author: MWS

text: By great application, however, and after having remained during the space of several revolutions of the moon in my hovel, I discovered the names that were given to some of the most familiar objects of discourse; I learned and applied the words, _fire, milk, bread,_ and _wood._ I learned also the names of the cottagers themselves.
author: MWS

text: The youth and his companion had each of them several names, but the old man had only one, which was _father._ The girl was called _sister_ or _Agatha,_ and the youth _Felix, brother,_ or _son_.
author: MWS

text: I cannot describe the delight I felt when I learned the ideas appropriated to each of these sounds and was able to pronounce them.
author: MWS

text: I distinguished several other words without being able as yet to understand or apply them, such as _good, dearest, unhappy._  “I spent the winter in this manner.
author: MWS

text: The gentle manners and beauty of the cottagers greatly endeared them to me; when they were unhappy, I felt depressed; when they rejoiced, I sympathised in their joys.
author: MWS

text: I saw few human beings besides them, and if any other happened to enter the cottage, their harsh manners and rude gait only enhanced to me the superior accomplishments of my friends.
author: MWS

text: The old man, I could perceive, often endeavoured to encourage his children, as sometimes I found that he called them, to cast off their melancholy.
author: MWS

text: He would talk in a cheerful accent, with an expression of goodness that bestowed pleasure even upon me.
author: MWS

text: Agatha listened with respect, her eyes sometimes filled with tears, which she endeavoured to wipe away unperceived; but I generally found that her countenance and tone were more cheerful after having listened to the exhortations of her father.
author: MWS

text: It was not thus with Felix.
author: MWS

text: He was always the saddest of the group, and even to my unpractised senses, he appeared to have suffered more deeply than his friends.
author: MWS

text: But if his countenance was more sorrowful, his voice was more cheerful than that of his sister, especially when he addressed the old man.
author: MWS

text: “I could mention innumerable instances which, although slight, marked the dispositions of these amiable cottagers.
author: MWS

text: In the midst of poverty and want, Felix carried with pleasure to his sister the first little white flower that peeped out from beneath the snowy ground.
author: MWS

text: Early in the morning, before she had risen, he cleared away the snow that obstructed her path to the milk-house, drew water from the well, and brought the wood from the outhouse, where, to his perpetual astonishment, he found his store always replenished by an invisible hand.
author: MWS

text: In the day, I believe, he worked sometimes for a neighbouring farmer, because he often went forth and did not return until dinner, yet brought no wood with him.
author: MWS

text: At other times he worked in the garden, but as there was little to do in the frosty season, he read to the old man and Agatha.
author: MWS

text: “This reading had puzzled me extremely at first, but by degrees I discovered that he uttered many of the same sounds when he read as when he talked.
author: MWS

text: I conjectured, therefore, that he found on the paper signs for speech which he understood, and I ardently longed to comprehend these also; but how was that possible when I did not even understand the sounds for which they stood as signs?
author: MWS

text: I improved, however, sensibly in this science, but not sufficiently to follow up any kind of conversation, although I applied my whole mind to the endeavour, for I easily perceived that, although I eagerly longed to discover myself to the cottagers, I ought not to make the attempt until I had first become master of their language, which knowledge might enable me to make them overlook the deformity of my figure, for with this also the contrast perpetually presented to my eyes had made me acquainted.
author: MWS

text: “I had admired the perfect forms of my cottagers—their grace, beauty, and delicate complexions; but how was I terrified when I viewed myself in a transparent pool!
author: MWS

text: At first I started back, unable to believe that it was indeed I who was reflected in the mirror; and when I became fully convinced that I was in reality the monster that I am, I was filled with the bitterest sensations of despondence and mortification.
author: MWS

text: I did not yet entirely know the fatal effects of this miserable deformity.
author: MWS

text: “As the sun became warmer and the light of day longer, the snow vanished, and I beheld the bare trees and the black earth.
author: MWS

text: From this time Felix was more employed, and the heart-moving indications of impending famine disappeared.
author: MWS

text: Their food, as I afterwards found, was coarse, but it was wholesome; and they procured a sufficiency of it.
author: MWS

text: Several new kinds of plants sprang up in the garden, which they dressed; and these signs of comfort increased daily as the season advanced.
author: MWS

text: “The old man, leaning on his son, walked each day at noon, when it did not rain, as I found it was called when the heavens poured forth its waters.
author: MWS

text: This frequently took place, but a high wind quickly dried the earth, and the season became far more pleasant than it had been.
author: MWS

text: “My mode of life in my hovel was uniform.
author: MWS

text: During the morning I attended the motions of the cottagers, and when they were dispersed in various occupations, I slept; the remainder of the day was spent in observing my friends.
author: MWS

text: When they had retired to rest, if there was any moon or the night was star-light, I went into the woods and collected my own food and fuel for the cottage.
author: MWS

text: When I returned, as often as it was necessary, I cleared their path from the snow and performed those offices that I had seen done by Felix.
author: MWS

text: I afterwards found that these labours, performed by an invisible hand, greatly astonished them; and once or twice I heard them, on these occasions, utter the words _good spirit, wonderful_; but I did not then understand the signification of these terms.
author: MWS

text: “My thoughts now became more active, and I longed to discover the motives and feelings of these lovely creatures; I was inquisitive to know why Felix appeared so miserable and Agatha so sad.
author: MWS

text: I thought (foolish wretch!)
author: MWS

text: that it might be in my power to restore happiness to these deserving people.
author: MWS

text: When I slept or was absent, the forms of the venerable blind father, the gentle Agatha, and the excellent Felix flitted before me.
author: MWS

text: I looked upon them as superior beings who would be the arbiters of my future destiny.
author: MWS

text: I formed in my imagination a thousand pictures of presenting myself to them, and their reception of me.
author: MWS

text: I imagined that they would be disgusted, until, by my gentle demeanour and conciliating words, I should first win their favour and afterwards their love.
author: MWS

text: “These thoughts exhilarated me and led me to apply with fresh ardour to the acquiring the art of language.
author: MWS

text: My organs were indeed harsh, but supple; and although my voice was very unlike the soft music of their tones, yet I pronounced such words as I understood with tolerable ease.
author: MWS

text: It was as the ass and the lap-dog; yet surely the gentle ass whose intentions were affectionate, although his manners were rude, deserved better treatment than blows and execration.
author: MWS

text: “The pleasant showers and genial warmth of spring greatly altered the aspect of the earth.
author: MWS

text: Men who before this change seemed to have been hid in caves dispersed themselves and were employed in various arts of cultivation.
author: MWS

text: The birds sang in more cheerful notes, and the leaves began to bud forth on the trees.
author: MWS

text: Fit habitation for gods, which, so short a time before, was bleak, damp, and unwholesome.
author: MWS

text: My spirits were elevated by the enchanting appearance of nature; the past was blotted from my memory, the present was tranquil, and the future gilded by bright rays of hope and anticipations of joy.”      Chapter 13  “I now hasten to the more moving part of my story.
author: MWS

text: I shall relate events that impressed me with feelings which, from what I had been, have made me what I am.
author: MWS

text: “Spring advanced rapidly; the weather became fine and the skies cloudless.
author: MWS

text: It surprised me that what before was desert and gloomy should now bloom with the most beautiful flowers and verdure.
author: MWS

text: My senses were gratified and refreshed by a thousand scents of delight and a thousand sights of beauty.
author: MWS

text: “It was on one of these days, when my cottagers periodically rested from labour—the old man played on his guitar, and the children listened to him—that I observed the countenance of Felix was melancholy beyond expression; he sighed frequently, and once his father paused in his music, and I conjectured by his manner that he inquired the cause of his son’s sorrow.
author: MWS

text: Felix replied in a cheerful accent, and the old man was recommencing his music when someone tapped at the door.
author: MWS

text: “It was a lady on horseback, accompanied by a country-man as a guide.
author: MWS

text: The lady was dressed in a dark suit and covered with a thick black veil.
author: MWS

text: Agatha asked a question, to which the stranger only replied by pronouncing, in a sweet accent, the name of Felix.
author: MWS

text: Her voice was musical but unlike that of either of my friends.
author: MWS

text: On hearing this word, Felix came up hastily to the lady, who, when she saw him, threw up her veil, and I beheld a countenance of angelic beauty and expression.
author: MWS

text: Her hair of a shining raven black, and curiously braided; her eyes were dark, but gentle, although animated; her features of a regular proportion, and her complexion wondrously fair, each cheek tinged with a lovely pink.
author: MWS

text: “Felix seemed ravished with delight when he saw her, every trait of sorrow vanished from his face, and it instantly expressed a degree of ecstatic joy, of which I could hardly have believed it capable; his eyes sparkled, as his cheek flushed with pleasure; and at that moment I thought him as beautiful as the stranger.
author: MWS

text: She appeared affected by different feelings; wiping a few tears from her lovely eyes, she held out her hand to Felix, who kissed it rapturously and called her, as well as I could distinguish, his sweet Arabian.
author: MWS

text: She did not appear to understand him, but smiled.
author: MWS

text: He assisted her to dismount, and dismissing her guide, conducted her into the cottage.
author: MWS

text: Some conversation took place between him and his father, and the young stranger knelt at the old man’s feet and would have kissed his hand, but he raised her and embraced her affectionately.
author: MWS

text: “I soon perceived that although the stranger uttered articulate sounds and appeared to have a language of her own, she was neither understood by nor herself understood the cottagers.
author: MWS

text: They made many signs which I did not comprehend, but I saw that her presence diffused gladness through the cottage, dispelling their sorrow as the sun dissipates the morning mists.
author: MWS

text: Felix seemed peculiarly happy and with smiles of delight welcomed his Arabian.
author: MWS

text: Agatha, the ever-gentle Agatha, kissed the hands of the lovely stranger, and pointing to her brother, made signs which appeared to me to mean that he had been sorrowful until she came.
author: MWS

text: Some hours passed thus, while they, by their countenances, expressed joy, the cause of which I did not comprehend.
author: MWS

text: Presently I found, by the frequent recurrence of some sound which the stranger repeated after them, that she was endeavouring to learn their language; and the idea instantly occurred to me that I should make use of the same instructions to the same end.
author: MWS

text: The stranger learned about twenty words at the first lesson; most of them, indeed, were those which I had before understood, but I profited by the others.
author: MWS

text: “As night came on, Agatha and the Arabian retired early.
author: MWS

text: When they separated Felix kissed the hand of the stranger and said, ‘Good night sweet Safie.’  He sat up much longer, conversing with his father, and by the frequent repetition of her name I conjectured that their lovely guest was the subject of their conversation.
author: MWS

text: I ardently desired to understand them, and bent every faculty towards that purpose, but found it utterly impossible.
author: MWS

text: “The next morning Felix went out to his work, and after the usual occupations of Agatha were finished, the Arabian sat at the feet of the old man, and taking his guitar, played some airs so entrancingly beautiful that they at once drew tears of sorrow and delight from my eyes.
author: MWS

text: She sang, and her voice flowed in a rich cadence, swelling or dying away like a nightingale of the woods.
author: MWS

text: “When she had finished, she gave the guitar to Agatha, who at first declined it.
author: MWS

text: She played a simple air, and her voice accompanied it in sweet accents, but unlike the wondrous strain of the stranger.
author: MWS

text: The old man appeared enraptured and said some words which Agatha endeavoured to explain to Safie, and by which he appeared to wish to express that she bestowed on him the greatest delight by her music.
author: MWS

text: “The days now passed as peaceably as before, with the sole alteration that joy had taken place of sadness in the countenances of my friends.
author: MWS

text: Safie was always gay and happy; she and I improved rapidly in the knowledge of language, so that in two months I began to comprehend most of the words uttered by my protectors.
author: MWS

text: “In the meanwhile also the black ground was covered with herbage, and the green banks interspersed with innumerable flowers, sweet to the scent and the eyes, stars of pale radiance among the moonlight woods; the sun became warmer, the nights clear and balmy; and my nocturnal rambles were an extreme pleasure to me, although they were considerably shortened by the late setting and early rising of the sun, for I never ventured abroad during daylight, fearful of meeting with the same treatment I had formerly endured in the first village which I entered.
author: MWS

text: “My days were spent in close attention, that I might more speedily master the language; and I may boast that I improved more rapidly than the Arabian, who understood very little and conversed in broken accents, whilst I comprehended and could imitate almost every word that was spoken.
author: MWS

text: “While I improved in speech, I also learned the science of letters as it was taught to the stranger, and this opened before me a wide field for wonder and delight.
author: MWS

text: “The book from which Felix instructed Safie was Volney’s _Ruins of Empires_.
author: MWS

text: I should not have understood the purport of this book had not Felix, in reading it, given very minute explanations.
author: MWS

text: He had chosen this work, he said, because the declamatory style was framed in imitation of the Eastern authors.
author: MWS

text: Through this work I obtained a cursory knowledge of history and a view of the several empires at present existing in the world; it gave me an insight into the manners, governments, and religions of the different nations of the earth.
author: MWS

text: I heard of the slothful Asiatics, of the stupendous genius and mental activity of the Grecians, of the wars and wonderful virtue of the early Romans—of their subsequent degenerating—of the decline of that mighty empire, of chivalry, Christianity, and kings.
author: MWS

text: I heard of the discovery of the American hemisphere and wept with Safie over the hapless fate of its original inhabitants.
author: MWS

text: “These wonderful narrations inspired me with strange feelings.
author: MWS

text: Was man, indeed, at once so powerful, so virtuous and magnificent, yet so vicious and base?
author: MWS

text: He appeared at one time a mere scion of the evil principle and at another as all that can be conceived of noble and godlike.
author: MWS

text: To be a great and virtuous man appeared the highest honour that can befall a sensitive being; to be base and vicious, as many on record have been, appeared the lowest degradation, a condition more abject than that of the blind mole or harmless worm.
author: MWS

text: For a long time I could not conceive how one man could go forth to murder his fellow, or even why there were laws and governments; but when I heard details of vice and bloodshed, my wonder ceased and I turned away with disgust and loathing.
author: MWS

text: “Every conversation of the cottagers now opened new wonders to me.
author: MWS

text: While I listened to the instructions which Felix bestowed upon the Arabian, the strange system of human society was explained to me.
author: MWS

text: I heard of the division of property, of immense wealth and squalid poverty, of rank, descent, and noble blood.
author: MWS

text: “The words induced me to turn towards myself.
author: MWS

text: I learned that the possessions most esteemed by your fellow creatures were high and unsullied descent united with riches.
author: MWS

text: A man might be respected with only one of these advantages, but without either he was considered, except in very rare instances, as a vagabond and a slave, doomed to waste his powers for the profits of the chosen few!
author: MWS

text: And what was I?
author: MWS

text: Of my creation and creator I was absolutely ignorant, but I knew that I possessed no money, no friends, no kind of property.
author: MWS

text: I was, besides, endued with a figure hideously deformed and loathsome; I was not even of the same nature as man.
author: MWS

text: I was more agile than they and could subsist upon coarser diet; I bore the extremes of heat and cold with less injury to my frame; my stature far exceeded theirs.
author: MWS

text: When I looked around I saw and heard of none like me.
author: MWS

text: Was I, then, a monster, a blot upon the earth, from which all men fled and whom all men disowned?
author: MWS

text: “I cannot describe to you the agony that these reflections inflicted upon me; I tried to dispel them, but sorrow only increased with knowledge.
author: MWS

text: Oh, that I had for ever remained in my native wood, nor known nor felt beyond the sensations of hunger, thirst, and heat!
author: MWS

text: “Of what a strange nature is knowledge!
author: MWS

text: It clings to the mind when it has once seized on it like a lichen on the rock.
author: MWS

text: I wished sometimes to shake off all thought and feeling, but I learned that there was but one means to overcome the sensation of pain, and that was death—a state which I feared yet did not understand.
author: MWS

text: I admired virtue and good feelings and loved the gentle manners and amiable qualities of my cottagers, but I was shut out from intercourse with them, except through means which I obtained by stealth, when I was unseen and unknown, and which rather increased than satisfied the desire I had of becoming one among my fellows.
author: MWS

text: The gentle words of Agatha and  the animated smiles of the charming Arabian were not for me.
author: MWS

text: The mild exhortations of the old man and the lively conversation of the loved Felix were not for me.
author: MWS

text: “Other lessons were impressed upon me even more deeply.
author: MWS

text: I heard of the difference of sexes, and the birth and growth of children, how the father doted on the smiles of the infant, and the lively sallies of the older child, how all the life and cares of the mother were wrapped up in the precious charge, how the mind of youth expanded and gained knowledge, of brother, sister, and all the various relationships which bind one human being to another in mutual bonds.
author: MWS

text: “But where were my friends and relations?
author: MWS

text: No father had watched my infant days, no mother had blessed me with smiles and caresses; or if they had, all my past life was now a blot, a blind vacancy in which I distinguished nothing.
author: MWS

text: From my earliest remembrance I had been as I then was in height and proportion.
author: MWS

text: I had never yet seen a being resembling me or who claimed any intercourse with me.
author: MWS

text: The question again recurred, to be answered only with groans.
author: MWS

text: “I will soon explain to what these feelings tended, but allow me now to return to the cottagers, whose story excited in me such various feelings of indignation, delight, and wonder, but which all terminated in additional love and reverence for my protectors (for so I loved, in an innocent, half-painful self-deceit, to call them).”      Chapter 14  “Some time elapsed before I learned the history of my friends.
author: MWS

text: It was one which could not fail to impress itself deeply on my mind, unfolding as it did a number of circumstances, each interesting and wonderful to one so utterly inexperienced as I was.
author: MWS

text: “The name of the old man was De Lacey.
author: MWS

text: He was descended from a good family in France, where he had lived for many years in affluence, respected by his superiors and beloved by his equals.
author: MWS

text: His son was bred in the service of his country, and Agatha had ranked with ladies of the highest distinction.
author: MWS

text: A few months before my arrival they had lived in a large and luxurious city called Paris, surrounded by friends and possessed of every enjoyment which virtue, refinement of intellect, or taste, accompanied by a moderate fortune, could afford.
author: MWS

text: “The father of Safie had been the cause of their ruin.
author: MWS

text: He was a Turkish merchant and had inhabited Paris for many years, when, for some reason which I could not learn, he became obnoxious to the government.
author: MWS

text: He was seized and cast into prison the very day that Safie arrived from Constantinople to join him.
author: MWS

text: He was tried and condemned to death.
author: MWS

text: The injustice of his sentence was very flagrant; all Paris was indignant; and it was judged that his religion and wealth rather than the crime alleged against him had been the cause of his condemnation.
author: MWS

text: “Felix had accidentally been present at the trial; his horror and indignation were uncontrollable when he heard the decision of the court.
author: MWS

text: He made, at that moment, a solemn vow to deliver him and then looked around for the means.
author: MWS

text: After many fruitless attempts to gain admittance to the prison, he found a strongly grated window in an unguarded part of the building, which lighted the dungeon of the unfortunate Muhammadan, who, loaded with chains, waited in despair the execution of the barbarous sentence.
author: MWS

text: Felix visited the grate at night and made known to the prisoner his intentions in his favour.
author: MWS

text: The Turk, amazed and delighted, endeavoured to kindle the zeal of his deliverer by promises of reward and wealth.
author: MWS

text: Felix rejected his offers with contempt, yet when he saw the lovely Safie, who was allowed to visit her father and who by her gestures expressed her lively gratitude, the youth could not help owning to his own mind that the captive possessed a treasure which would fully reward his toil and hazard.
author: MWS

text: “The Turk quickly perceived the impression that his daughter had made on the heart of Felix and endeavoured to secure him more entirely in his interests by the promise of her hand in marriage so soon as he should be conveyed to a place of safety.
author: MWS

text: Felix was too delicate to accept this offer, yet he looked forward to the probability of the event as to the consummation of his happiness.
author: MWS

text: “During the ensuing days, while the preparations were going forward for the escape of the merchant, the zeal of Felix was warmed by several letters that he received from this lovely girl, who found means to express her thoughts in the language of her lover by the aid of an old man, a servant of her father who understood French.
author: MWS

text: She thanked him in the most ardent terms for his intended services towards her parent, and at the same time she gently deplored her own fate.
author: MWS

text: “I have copies of these letters, for I found means, during my residence in the hovel, to procure the implements of writing; and the letters were often in the hands of Felix or Agatha.
author: MWS

text: Before I depart I will give them to you; they will prove the truth of my tale; but at present, as the sun is already far declined, I shall only have time to repeat the substance of them to you.
author: MWS

text: “Safie related that her mother was a Christian Arab, seized and made a slave by the Turks; recommended by her beauty, she had won the heart of the father of Safie, who married her.
author: MWS

text: The young girl spoke in high and enthusiastic terms of her mother, who, born in freedom, spurned the bondage to which she was now reduced.
author: MWS

text: She instructed her daughter in the tenets of her religion and taught her to aspire to higher powers of intellect and an independence of spirit forbidden to the female followers of Muhammad.
author: MWS

text: This lady died, but her lessons were indelibly impressed on the mind of Safie, who sickened at the prospect of again returning to Asia and being immured within the walls of a harem, allowed only to occupy herself with infantile amusements, ill-suited to the temper of her soul, now accustomed to grand ideas and a noble emulation for virtue.
author: MWS

text: The prospect of marrying a Christian and remaining in a country where women were allowed to take a rank in society was enchanting to her.
author: MWS

text: “The day for the execution of the Turk was fixed, but on the night previous to it he quitted his prison and before morning was distant many leagues from Paris.
author: MWS

text: Felix had procured passports in the name of his father, sister, and himself.
author: MWS

text: He had previously communicated his plan to the former, who aided the deceit by quitting his house, under the pretence of a journey and concealed himself, with his daughter, in an obscure part of Paris.
author: MWS

text: “Felix conducted the fugitives through France to Lyons and across Mont Cenis to Leghorn, where the merchant had decided to wait a favourable opportunity of passing into some part of the Turkish dominions.
author: MWS

text: “Safie resolved to remain with her father until the moment of his departure, before which time the Turk renewed his promise that she should be united to his deliverer; and Felix remained with them in expectation of that event; and in the meantime he enjoyed the society of the Arabian, who exhibited towards him the simplest and tenderest affection.
author: MWS

text: They conversed with one another through the means of an interpreter, and sometimes with the interpretation of looks; and Safie sang to him the divine airs of her native country.
author: MWS

text: “The Turk allowed this intimacy to take place and encouraged the hopes of the youthful lovers, while in his heart he had formed far other plans.
author: MWS

text: He loathed the idea that his daughter should be united to a Christian, but he feared the resentment of Felix if he should appear lukewarm, for he knew that he was still in the power of his deliverer if he should choose to betray him to the Italian state which they inhabited.
author: MWS

text: He revolved a thousand plans by which he should be enabled to prolong the deceit until it might be no longer necessary, and secretly to take his daughter with him when he departed.
author: MWS

text: His plans were facilitated by the news which arrived from Paris.
author: MWS

text: “The government of France were greatly enraged at the escape of their victim and spared no pains to detect and punish his deliverer.
author: MWS

text: The plot of Felix was quickly discovered, and De Lacey and Agatha were thrown into prison.
author: MWS

text: The news reached Felix and roused him from his dream of pleasure.
author: MWS

text: His blind and aged father and his gentle sister lay in a noisome dungeon while he enjoyed the free air and the society of her whom he loved.
author: MWS

text: This idea was torture to him.
author: MWS

text: He quickly arranged with the Turk that if the latter should find a favourable opportunity for escape before Felix could return to Italy, Safie should remain as a boarder at a convent at Leghorn; and then, quitting the lovely Arabian, he hastened to Paris and delivered himself up to the vengeance of the law, hoping to free De Lacey and Agatha by this proceeding.
author: MWS

text: “He did not succeed.
author: MWS

text: They remained confined for five months before the trial took place, the result of which deprived them of their fortune and condemned them to a perpetual exile from their native country.
author: MWS

text: “They found a miserable asylum in the cottage in Germany, where I discovered them.
author: MWS

text: Felix soon learned that the treacherous Turk, for whom he and his family endured such unheard-of oppression, on discovering that his deliverer was thus reduced to poverty and ruin, became a traitor to good feeling and honour and had quitted Italy with his daughter, insultingly sending Felix a pittance of money to aid him, as he said, in some plan of future maintenance.
author: MWS

text: “Such were the events that preyed on the heart of Felix and rendered him, when I first saw him, the most miserable of his family.
author: MWS

text: He could have endured poverty, and while this distress had been the meed of his virtue, he gloried in it; but the ingratitude of the Turk and the loss of his beloved Safie were misfortunes more bitter and irreparable.
author: MWS

text: The arrival of the Arabian now infused new life into his soul.
author: MWS

text: “When the news reached Leghorn that Felix was deprived of his wealth and rank, the merchant commanded his daughter to think no more of her lover, but to prepare to return to her native country.
author: MWS

text: The generous nature of Safie was outraged by this command; she attempted to expostulate with her father, but he left her angrily, reiterating his tyrannical mandate.
author: MWS

text: “A few days after, the Turk entered his daughter’s apartment and told her hastily that he had reason to believe that his residence at Leghorn had been divulged and that he should speedily be delivered up to the French government; he had consequently hired a vessel to convey him to Constantinople, for which city he should sail in a few hours.
author: MWS

text: He intended to leave his daughter under the care of a confidential servant, to follow at her leisure with the greater part of his property, which had not yet arrived at Leghorn.
author: MWS

text: “When alone, Safie resolved in her own mind the plan of conduct that it would become her to pursue in this emergency.
author: MWS

text: A residence in Turkey was abhorrent to her; her religion and her feelings were alike averse to it.
author: MWS

text: By some papers of her father which fell into her hands she heard of the exile of her lover and learnt the name of the spot where he then resided.
author: MWS

text: She hesitated some time, but at length she formed her determination.
author: MWS

text: Taking with her some jewels that belonged to her and a sum of money, she quitted Italy with an attendant, a native of Leghorn, but who understood the common language of Turkey, and departed for Germany.
author: MWS

text: “She arrived in safety at a town about twenty leagues from the cottage of De Lacey, when her attendant fell dangerously ill.  Safie nursed her with the most devoted affection, but the poor girl died, and the Arabian was left alone, unacquainted with the language of the country and utterly ignorant of the customs of the world.
author: MWS

text: She fell, however, into good hands.
author: MWS

text: The Italian had mentioned the name of the spot for which they were bound, and after her death the woman of the house in which they had lived took care that Safie should arrive in safety at the cottage of her lover.”      Chapter 15  “Such was the history of my beloved cottagers.
author: MWS

text: It impressed me deeply.
author: MWS

text: I learned, from the views of social life which it developed, to admire their virtues and to deprecate the vices of mankind.
author: MWS

text: “As yet I looked upon crime as a distant evil, benevolence and generosity were ever present before me, inciting within me a desire to become an actor in the busy scene where so many admirable qualities were called forth and displayed.
author: MWS

text: But in giving an account of the progress of my intellect, I must not omit a circumstance which occurred in the beginning of the month of August of the same year.
author: MWS

text: “One night during my accustomed visit to the neighbouring wood where I collected my own food and brought home firing for my protectors, I found on the ground a leathern portmanteau containing several articles of dress and some books.
author: MWS

text: I eagerly seized the prize and returned with it to my hovel.
author: MWS

text: Fortunately the books were written in the language, the elements of which I had acquired at the cottage; they consisted of _Paradise Lost_, a volume of _Plutarch’s Lives_, and the _Sorrows of Werter_.
author: MWS

text: The possession of these treasures gave me extreme delight; I now continually studied and exercised my mind upon these histories, whilst my friends were employed in their ordinary occupations.
author: MWS

text: “I can hardly describe to you the effect of these books.
author: MWS

text: They produced in me an infinity of new images and feelings, that sometimes raised me to ecstasy, but more frequently sunk me into the lowest dejection.
author: MWS

text: In the _Sorrows of Werter_, besides the interest of its simple and affecting story, so many opinions are canvassed and so many lights thrown upon what had hitherto been to me obscure subjects that I found in it a never-ending source of speculation and astonishment.
author: MWS

text: The gentle and domestic manners it described, combined with lofty sentiments and feelings, which had for their object something out of self, accorded well with my experience among my protectors and with the wants which were for ever alive in my own bosom.
author: MWS

text: But I thought Werter himself a more divine being than I had ever beheld or imagined; his character contained no pretension, but it sank deep.
author: MWS

text: The disquisitions upon death and suicide were calculated to fill  me with wonder.
author: MWS

text: I did not pretend to enter into the merits of the case, yet I inclined towards the opinions of the hero, whose extinction I wept, without precisely understanding it.
author: MWS

text: “As I read, however, I applied much personally to my own feelings and condition.
author: MWS

text: I found myself similar yet at the same time strangely unlike to the beings concerning whom I read and to whose conversation I was a listener.
author: MWS

text: I sympathised with and partly understood them, but I was unformed in mind; I was dependent on none and related to none.
author: MWS

text: ‘The path of my departure was free,’ and there was none to lament my annihilation.
author: MWS

text: My person was hideous and my stature gigantic.
author: MWS

text: What did this mean?
author: MWS

text: Whence did I come?
author: MWS

text: What was my destination?
author: MWS

text: These questions continually recurred, but I was unable to solve them.
author: MWS

text: “The volume of _Plutarch’s Lives_ which I possessed contained the histories of the first founders of the ancient republics.
author: MWS

text: This book had a far different effect upon me from the _Sorrows of Werter_.
author: MWS

text: I learned from Werter’s imaginations despondency and gloom, but Plutarch taught me high thoughts; he elevated me above the wretched sphere of my own reflections, to admire and love the heroes of past ages.
author: MWS

text: Many things I read surpassed my understanding and experience.
author: MWS

text: I had a very confused knowledge of kingdoms, wide extents of country, mighty rivers, and boundless seas.
author: MWS

text: But I was perfectly unacquainted with towns and large assemblages of men.
author: MWS

text: The cottage of my protectors had been the only school in which I had studied human nature, but this book developed new and mightier scenes of action.
author: MWS

text: I read of men concerned in public affairs, governing or massacring their species.
author: MWS

text: I felt the greatest ardour for virtue rise within me, and abhorrence for vice, as far as I understood the signification of those terms, relative as they were, as I applied them, to pleasure and pain alone.
author: MWS

text: Induced by these feelings, I was of course led to admire peaceable lawgivers, Numa, Solon, and Lycurgus, in preference to Romulus and Theseus.
author: MWS

text: The patriarchal lives of my protectors caused these impressions to take a firm hold on my mind; perhaps, if my first introduction to humanity had been made by a young soldier, burning for glory and slaughter, I should have been imbued with different sensations.
author: MWS

text: “But _Paradise Lost_ excited different and far deeper emotions.
author: MWS

text: I read it, as I had read the other volumes which had fallen into my hands, as a true history.
author: MWS

text: It moved every feeling of wonder and awe that the picture of an omnipotent God warring with his creatures was capable of exciting.
author: MWS

text: I often referred the several situations, as their similarity struck me, to my own.
author: MWS

text: Like Adam, I was apparently united by no link to any other being in existence; but his state was far different from mine in every other respect.
author: MWS

text: He had come forth from the hands of God a perfect creature, happy and prosperous, guarded by the especial care of his Creator; he was allowed to converse with and acquire knowledge from beings of a superior nature, but I was wretched, helpless, and alone.
author: MWS

text: Many times I considered Satan as the fitter emblem of my condition, for often, like him, when I viewed the bliss of my protectors, the bitter gall of envy rose within me.
author: MWS

text: “Another circumstance strengthened and confirmed these feelings.
author: MWS

text: Soon after my arrival in the hovel I discovered some papers in the pocket of the dress which I had taken from your laboratory.
author: MWS

text: At first I had neglected them, but now that I was able to decipher the characters in which they were written, I began to study them with diligence.
author: MWS

text: It was your journal of the four months that preceded my creation.
author: MWS

text: You minutely described in these papers every step you took in the progress of your work; this history was mingled with accounts of domestic occurrences.
author: MWS

text: You doubtless recollect these papers.
author: MWS

text: Everything is related in them which bears reference to my accursed origin; the whole detail of that series of disgusting circumstances which produced it is set in view; the minutest description of my odious and loathsome person is given, in language which painted your own horrors and rendered mine indelible.
author: MWS

text: I sickened as I read.
author: MWS

text: ‘Hateful day when I received life!’ I exclaimed in agony.
author: MWS

text: Why did you form a monster so hideous that even _you_ turned from me in disgust?
author: MWS

text: God, in pity, made man beautiful and alluring, after his own image; but my form is a filthy type of yours, more horrid even from the very resemblance.
author: MWS

text: Satan had his companions, fellow devils, to admire and encourage him, but I am solitary and abhorred.’  “These were the reflections of my hours of despondency and solitude; but when I contemplated the virtues of the cottagers, their amiable and benevolent dispositions, I persuaded myself that when they should become acquainted with my admiration of their virtues they  would compassionate me and overlook my personal deformity.
author: MWS

text: Could they turn from their door one, however monstrous, who solicited their compassion and friendship?
author: MWS

text: I resolved, at least, not to despair, but in every way to fit myself for an interview with them which would decide my fate.
author: MWS

text: I postponed this attempt for some months longer, for the importance attached to its success inspired me with a dread lest I should fail.
author: MWS

text: Besides, I found that my understanding improved so much with every day’s experience that I was unwilling to commence this undertaking until a few more months should have added to my sagacity.
author: MWS

text: “Several changes, in the meantime, took place in the cottage.
author: MWS

text: The presence of Safie diffused happiness among its inhabitants, and I also found that a greater degree of plenty reigned there.
author: MWS

text: Felix and Agatha spent more time in amusement and conversation, and were assisted in their labours by servants.
author: MWS

text: They did not appear rich, but they were contented and happy; their feelings were serene and peaceful, while mine became every day more tumultuous.
author: MWS

text: Increase of knowledge only discovered to me more clearly what a wretched outcast I was.
author: MWS

text: I cherished hope, it is true, but it vanished when I beheld my person reflected in water or my shadow in the moonshine, even as that frail image and that inconstant shade.
author: MWS

text: “I endeavoured to crush these fears and to fortify myself for the trial which in a few months I resolved to undergo; and sometimes I allowed my thoughts, unchecked by reason, to ramble in the fields of Paradise, and dared to fancy amiable and lovely creatures sympathising with my feelings and cheering my gloom; their angelic countenances breathed smiles of consolation.
author: MWS

text: But it was all a dream; no Eve soothed my sorrows nor shared my thoughts; I was alone.
author: MWS

text: I remembered Adam’s supplication to his Creator.
author: MWS

text: But where was mine?
author: MWS

text: He had abandoned me, and in the bitterness of my heart I cursed him.
author: MWS

text: I saw, with surprise and grief, the leaves decay and fall, and nature again assume the barren and bleak appearance it had worn when I first beheld the woods and the lovely moon.
author: MWS

text: Yet I did not heed the bleakness of the weather; I was better fitted by my conformation for the endurance of cold than heat.
author: MWS

text: But my chief delights were the sight of the flowers, the birds, and all the gay apparel of summer; when those deserted me, I turned with more attention towards the cottagers.
author: MWS

text: Their happiness was not decreased by the absence of summer.
author: MWS

text: They loved and sympathised with one another; and their joys, depending on each other, were not interrupted by the casualties that took place around them.
author: MWS

text: The more I saw of them, the greater became my desire to claim their protection and kindness; my heart yearned to be known and loved by these amiable creatures; to see their sweet looks directed towards me with affection was the utmost limit of my ambition.
author: MWS

text: I dared not think that they would turn them from me with disdain and horror.
author: MWS

text: The poor that stopped at their door were never driven away.
author: MWS

text: I asked, it is true, for greater treasures than a little food or rest:  I required kindness and sympathy; but I did not believe myself utterly unworthy of it.
author: MWS

text: “The winter advanced, and an entire revolution of the seasons had taken place since I awoke into life.
author: MWS

text: My attention at this time was solely directed towards my plan of introducing myself into the cottage of my protectors.
author: MWS

text: I revolved many projects, but that on which I finally fixed was to enter the dwelling when the blind old man should be alone.
author: MWS

text: I had sagacity enough to discover that the unnatural hideousness of my person was the chief object of horror with those who had formerly beheld me.
author: MWS

text: My voice, although harsh, had nothing terrible in it; I thought, therefore, that if in the absence of his children I could gain the good will and mediation of the old De Lacey, I might by his means be tolerated by my younger protectors.
author: MWS

text: “One day, when the sun shone on the red leaves that strewed the ground and diffused cheerfulness, although it denied warmth, Safie, Agatha, and Felix departed on a long country walk, and the old man, at his own desire, was left alone in the cottage.
author: MWS

text: When his children had departed, he took up his guitar and played several mournful but sweet airs, more sweet and mournful than I had ever heard him play before.
author: MWS

text: At first his countenance was illuminated with pleasure, but as he continued, thoughtfulness and sadness succeeded; at length, laying aside the instrument, he sat absorbed in reflection.
author: MWS

text: “My heart beat quick; this was the hour and moment of trial, which would decide my hopes or realise my fears.
author: MWS

text: The servants were gone to a neighbouring fair.
author: MWS

text: All was silent in and around the cottage; it was an excellent opportunity; yet, when I proceeded to execute my plan, my limbs failed me and I sank to the ground.
author: MWS

text: Again I rose, and exerting all the firmness of which I was master, removed the planks which I had placed before my hovel to conceal my retreat.
author: MWS

text: The fresh air revived me, and with renewed determination I approached the door of their cottage.
author: MWS

text: ‘Who is there?’ said the old man.
author: MWS

text: ‘Come in.’  “I entered.
author: MWS

text: ‘Pardon this intrusion,’ said I; ‘I am a traveller in want of a little rest; you would greatly oblige me if you would allow me to remain a few minutes before the fire.’  “‘Enter,’ said De Lacey, ‘and I will try in what manner I can to relieve your wants; but, unfortunately, my children are from home, and as I am blind, I am afraid I shall find it difficult to procure food for you.’  “‘Do not trouble yourself, my kind host; I have food; it is warmth and rest only that I need.’  “I sat down, and a silence ensued.
author: MWS

text: I knew that every minute was precious to me, yet I remained irresolute in what manner to commence the interview, when the old man addressed me.
author: MWS

text: ‘By your language, stranger, I suppose you are my countryman; are you French?’  “‘No; but I was educated by a French family and understand that language only.
author: MWS

text: I am now going to claim the protection of some friends, whom I sincerely love, and of whose favour I have some hopes.’  “‘Are they Germans?’  “‘No, they are French.
author: MWS

text: But let us change the subject.
author: MWS

text: I am an unfortunate and deserted creature, I look around and I have no relation or friend upon earth.
author: MWS

text: These amiable people to whom I go have never seen me and know little of me.
author: MWS

text: I am full of fears, for if I fail there, I am an outcast in the world for ever.’  “‘Do not despair.
author: MWS

text: To be friendless is indeed to be unfortunate, but the hearts of men, when unprejudiced by any obvious self-interest, are full of brotherly love and charity.
author: MWS

text: Rely, therefore, on your hopes; and if these friends are good and amiable, do not despair.’  “‘They are kind—they are the most excellent creatures in the world; but, unfortunately, they are prejudiced against me.
author: MWS

text: I have good dispositions; my life has been hitherto harmless and in some degree beneficial; but a fatal prejudice clouds their eyes, and where they ought to see a feeling and kind friend, they behold only a detestable monster.’  “‘That is indeed unfortunate; but if you are really blameless, cannot you undeceive them?’  “‘I am about to undertake that task; and it is on that account that I feel so many overwhelming terrors.
author: MWS

text: I tenderly love these friends; I have, unknown to them, been for many months in the habits of daily kindness towards them; but they believe that I wish to injure them, and it is that prejudice which I wish to overcome.’  “‘Where do these friends reside?’  “‘Near this spot.’  “The old man paused and then continued, ‘If you will unreservedly confide to me the particulars of your tale, I perhaps may be of use in undeceiving them.
author: MWS

text: I am blind and cannot judge of your countenance, but there is something in your words which persuades me that you are sincere.
author: MWS

text: I am poor and an exile, but it will afford me true pleasure to be in any way serviceable to a human creature.’  “‘Excellent man!
author: MWS

text: I thank you and accept your generous offer.
author: MWS

text: You raise me from the dust by this kindness; and I trust that, by your aid, I shall not be driven from the society and sympathy of your fellow creatures.’  “‘Heaven forbid!
author: MWS

text: Even if you were really criminal, for that can only drive you to desperation, and not instigate you to virtue.
author: MWS

text: I also am unfortunate; I and my family have been condemned, although innocent; judge, therefore, if I do not feel for your misfortunes.’  “‘How can I thank you, my best and only benefactor?
author: MWS

text: From your lips first have I heard the voice of kindness directed towards me; I shall be for ever grateful; and your present humanity assures me of success with those friends whom I am on the point of meeting.’  “‘May I know the names and residence of those friends?’  “I paused.
author: MWS

text: This, I thought, was the moment of decision, which was to rob me of or bestow happiness on me for ever.
author: MWS

text: I struggled vainly for firmness sufficient to answer him, but the effort destroyed all my remaining strength; I sank on the chair and sobbed aloud.
author: MWS

text: At that moment I heard the steps of my younger protectors.
author: MWS

text: I had not a moment to lose, but seizing the hand of the old man, I cried, ‘Now is the time!
author: MWS

text: Save and protect me!
author: MWS

text: You and your family are the friends whom I seek.
author: MWS

text: Do not you desert me in the hour of trial!’  “‘Great God!’ exclaimed the old man.
author: MWS

text: ‘Who are you?’  “At that instant the cottage door was opened, and Felix, Safie, and Agatha entered.
author: MWS

text: Who can describe their horror and consternation on beholding me?
author: MWS

text: Agatha fainted, and Safie, unable to attend to her friend, rushed out of the cottage.
author: MWS

text: Felix darted forward, and with supernatural force tore me from his father, to whose knees I clung, in a transport of fury, he dashed me to the ground and struck me violently with a stick.
author: MWS

text: I could have torn him limb from limb, as the lion rends the antelope.
author: MWS

text: But my heart sank within me as with bitter sickness, and I refrained.
author: MWS

text: I saw him on the point of repeating his blow, when, overcome by pain and anguish, I quitted the cottage, and in the general tumult escaped unperceived to my hovel.”      Chapter 16  “Cursed, cursed creator!
author: MWS

text: Why did I live?
author: MWS

text: Why, in that instant, did I not extinguish the spark of existence which you had so wantonly bestowed?
author: MWS

text: I know not; despair had not yet taken possession of me; my feelings were those of rage and revenge.
author: MWS

text: I could with pleasure have destroyed the cottage and its inhabitants and have glutted myself with their shrieks and misery.
author: MWS

text: “When night came I quitted my retreat and wandered in the wood; and now, no longer restrained by the fear of discovery, I gave vent to my anguish in fearful howlings.
author: MWS

text: I was like a wild beast that had broken the toils, destroying the objects that obstructed me and ranging through the wood with a stag-like swiftness.
author: MWS

text: What a miserable night I passed!
author: MWS

text: The cold stars shone in mockery, and the bare trees waved their branches above me; now and then the sweet voice of a bird burst forth amidst the universal stillness.
author: MWS

text: All, save I, were at rest or in enjoyment; I, like the arch-fiend, bore a hell within me, and finding myself unsympathised with, wished to tear up the trees, spread havoc and destruction around me, and then to have sat down and enjoyed the ruin.
author: MWS

text: “But this was a luxury of sensation that could not endure; I became fatigued with excess of bodily exertion and sank on the damp grass in the sick impotence of despair.
author: MWS

text: There was none among the myriads of men that existed who would pity or assist me; and should I feel kindness towards my enemies?
author: MWS

text: No; from that moment I declared everlasting war against the species, and more than all, against him who had formed me and sent me forth to this insupportable misery.
author: MWS

text: “The sun rose; I heard the voices of men and knew that it was impossible to return to my retreat during that day.
author: MWS

text: Accordingly I hid myself in some thick underwood, determining to devote the ensuing hours to reflection on my situation.
author: MWS

text: “The pleasant sunshine and the pure air of day restored me to some degree of tranquillity; and when I considered what had passed at the cottage, I could not help believing that I had been too hasty in my conclusions.
author: MWS

text: I had certainly acted imprudently.
author: MWS

text: It was apparent that my conversation had interested the father in my behalf, and  I was a fool in having exposed my person to the horror of his children.
author: MWS

text: I ought to have familiarised the old De Lacey to me, and by degrees to have discovered myself to the rest of his family, when they should have been  prepared for my approach.
author: MWS

text: But I did not believe my errors to be irretrievable, and after much consideration I resolved to return to the cottage, seek the old man, and by my representations win him to my party.
author: MWS

text: “These thoughts calmed me, and in the afternoon I sank into a profound sleep; but the fever of my blood did not allow me to be visited by peaceful dreams.
author: MWS

text: The horrible scene of the preceding day was for ever acting before my eyes; the females were flying and the enraged Felix tearing me from his father’s feet.
author: MWS

text: I awoke exhausted, and finding that it was already night, I crept forth from my hiding-place, and went in search of food.
author: MWS

text: “When my hunger was appeased, I directed my steps towards the well-known path that conducted to the cottage.
author: MWS

text: All there was at peace.
author: MWS

text: I crept into my hovel and remained in silent expectation of the accustomed hour when the family arose.
author: MWS

text: That hour passed, the sun mounted high in the heavens, but the cottagers did not appear.
author: MWS

text: I trembled violently, apprehending some dreadful misfortune.
author: MWS

text: The inside of the cottage was dark, and I heard no motion; I cannot describe the agony of this suspense.
author: MWS

text: “Presently two countrymen passed by, but pausing near the cottage, they entered into conversation, using violent gesticulations; but I did not understand what they said, as they spoke the language of the country, which differed from that of my protectors.
author: MWS

text: Soon after, however, Felix approached with another man; I was surprised, as I knew that he had not quitted the cottage that morning, and waited anxiously to discover from his discourse the meaning of these unusual appearances.
author: MWS

text: “‘Do you consider,’ said his companion to him, ‘that you will be obliged to pay three months’ rent and to lose the produce of your garden?
author: MWS

text: I do not wish to take any unfair advantage, and I beg therefore that you will take some days to consider of your determination.’  “‘It is utterly useless,’ replied Felix; ‘we can never again inhabit your cottage.
author: MWS

text: The life of my father is in the greatest danger, owing to the dreadful circumstance that I have related.
author: MWS

text: My wife and my sister will never recover from their horror.
author: MWS

text: I entreat you not to reason with me any more.
author: MWS

text: Take possession of your tenement and let me fly from this place.’  “Felix trembled violently as he said this.
author: MWS

text: He and his companion entered the cottage, in which they remained for a few minutes, and then departed.
author: MWS

text: I never saw any of the family of De Lacey more.
author: MWS

text: “I continued for the remainder of the day in my hovel in a state of utter and stupid despair.
author: MWS

text: My protectors had departed and had broken the only link that held me to the world.
author: MWS

text: For the first time the feelings of revenge and hatred filled my bosom, and I did not strive to control them, but allowing myself to be borne away by the stream, I bent my mind towards injury and death.
author: MWS

text: When I thought of my friends, of the mild voice of De Lacey, the gentle eyes of Agatha, and the exquisite beauty of the Arabian, these thoughts vanished and a gush of tears somewhat soothed me.
author: MWS

text: But again when I reflected that they had spurned and deserted me, anger returned, a rage of anger, and unable to injure anything human, I turned my fury towards inanimate objects.
author: MWS

text: As night advanced, I placed a variety of combustibles around the cottage, and after having destroyed every vestige of cultivation in the garden, I waited with forced impatience until the moon had sunk to commence my operations.
author: MWS

text: “As the night advanced, a fierce wind arose from the woods and quickly dispersed the clouds that had loitered in the heavens; the blast tore along like a mighty avalanche and produced a kind of insanity in my spirits that burst all bounds of reason and reflection.
author: MWS

text: I lighted the dry branch of a tree and danced with fury around the devoted cottage, my eyes still fixed on the western horizon, the edge of which the moon nearly touched.
author: MWS

text: A part of its orb was at length hid, and I waved my brand; it sank, and with a loud scream I fired the straw, and heath, and bushes, which I had collected.
author: MWS

text: The wind fanned the fire, and the cottage was quickly enveloped by the flames, which clung to it and licked it with their forked and destroying tongues.
author: MWS

text: “As soon as I was convinced that no assistance could save any part of the habitation, I quitted the scene and sought for refuge in the woods.
author: MWS

text: “And now, with the world before me, whither should I bend my steps?
author: MWS

text: I resolved to fly far from the scene of my misfortunes; but to me, hated and despised, every country must be equally horrible.
author: MWS

text: At length the thought of you crossed my mind.
author: MWS

text: I learned from your papers that you were my father, my creator; and to whom could I apply with more fitness than to him who had given me life?
author: MWS

text: Among the lessons that Felix had bestowed upon Safie, geography had not been omitted; I had learned from these the relative situations of the different countries of the earth.
author: MWS

text: You had mentioned Geneva as the name of your native town, and towards this place I resolved to proceed.
author: MWS

text: “But how was I to direct myself?
author: MWS

text: I knew that I must travel in a southwesterly direction to reach my destination, but the sun was my only guide.
author: MWS

text: I did not know the names of the towns that I was to pass through, nor could I ask information from a single human being; but I did not despair.
author: MWS

text: From you only could I hope for succour, although towards you I felt no sentiment but that of hatred.
author: MWS

text: You had endowed me with perceptions and passions and then cast me abroad an object for the scorn and horror of mankind.
author: MWS

text: But on you only had I any claim for pity and redress, and from you I determined to seek that justice which I vainly attempted to gain from any other being that wore the human form.
author: MWS

text: “My travels were long and the sufferings I endured intense.
author: MWS

text: It was late in autumn when I quitted the district where I had so long resided.
author: MWS

text: I travelled only at night, fearful of encountering the visage of a human being.
author: MWS

text: Nature decayed around me, and the sun became heatless; rain and snow poured around me; mighty rivers were frozen; the surface of the earth was hard and chill, and bare, and I found no shelter.
author: MWS

text: How often did I imprecate curses on the cause of my being!
author: MWS

text: The mildness of my nature had fled, and all within me was turned to gall and bitterness.
author: MWS

text: The nearer I approached to your habitation, the more deeply did I feel the spirit of revenge enkindled in my heart.
author: MWS

text: Snow fell, and the waters were hardened, but I rested not.
author: MWS

text: A few incidents now and then directed me, and I possessed a map of the country; but I often wandered wide from my path.
author: MWS

text: The agony of my feelings allowed me no respite; no incident occurred from which my rage and misery could not extract its food; but a circumstance that happened when I arrived on the confines of Switzerland, when the sun had recovered its warmth and the earth again began to look green, confirmed in an especial manner the bitterness and horror of my feelings.
author: MWS

text: “I generally rested during the day and travelled only when I was secured by night from the view of man.
author: MWS

text: One morning, however, finding that my path lay through a deep wood, I ventured to continue my journey after the sun had risen; the day, which was one of the first of spring, cheered even me by the loveliness of its sunshine and the balminess of the air.
author: MWS

text: I felt emotions of gentleness and pleasure, that had long appeared dead, revive within me.
author: MWS

text: Half surprised by the novelty of these sensations, I allowed myself to be borne away by them, and forgetting my solitude and deformity, dared to be happy.
author: MWS

text: Soft tears again bedewed my cheeks, and I even raised my humid eyes with thankfulness towards the blessed sun, which bestowed such joy upon me.
author: MWS

text: “I continued to wind among the paths of the wood, until I came to its boundary, which was skirted by a deep and rapid river, into which many of the trees bent their branches, now budding with the fresh spring.
author: MWS

text: Here I paused, not exactly knowing what path to pursue, when I heard the sound of voices, that induced me to conceal myself under the shade of a cypress.
author: MWS

text: I was scarcely hid when a young girl came running towards the spot where I was concealed, laughing, as if she ran from someone in sport.
author: MWS

text: She continued her course along the precipitous sides of the river, when suddenly her foot slipped, and she fell into the rapid stream.
author: MWS

text: I rushed from my hiding-place and with extreme labour, from the force of the current, saved her and dragged her to shore.
author: MWS

text: She was senseless, and I endeavoured by every means in my power to restore animation, when I was suddenly interrupted by the approach of a rustic, who was probably the person from whom she had playfully fled.
author: MWS

text: On seeing me, he darted towards me, and tearing the girl from my arms, hastened towards the deeper parts of the wood.
author: MWS

text: I followed speedily, I hardly knew why; but when the man saw me draw near, he aimed a gun, which he carried, at my body and fired.
author: MWS

text: I sank to the ground, and my injurer, with increased swiftness, escaped into the wood.
author: MWS

text: “This was then the reward of my benevolence!
author: MWS

text: I had saved a human being from destruction, and as a recompense I now writhed under the miserable pain of a wound which shattered the flesh and bone.

text: The feelings of kindness and gentleness which I had entertained but a few moments before gave place to hellish rage and gnashing of teeth.

text: “For some weeks I led a miserable life in the woods, endeavouring to cure the wound which I had received.
author: MWS

text: The ball had entered my shoulder, and I knew not whether it had remained there or passed through; at any rate I had no means of extracting it.
author: MWS

text: My sufferings were augmented also by the oppressive sense of the injustice and ingratitude of their infliction.
author: MWS

text: My daily vows rose for revenge—a deep and deadly revenge, such as would alone compensate for the outrages and anguish I had endured.
author: MWS

text: “After some weeks my wound healed, and I continued my journey.
author: MWS

text: The labours I endured were no longer to be alleviated by the bright sun or gentle breezes of spring; all joy was but a mockery which insulted my desolate state and made me feel more painfully that I was not made for the enjoyment of pleasure.
author: MWS

text: “But my toils now drew near a close, and in two months from this time I reached the environs of Geneva.
author: MWS

text: “It was evening when I arrived, and I retired to a hiding-place among the fields that surround it to meditate in what manner I should apply to you.
author: MWS

text: I was oppressed by fatigue and hunger and far too unhappy to enjoy the gentle breezes of evening or the prospect of the sun setting behind the stupendous mountains of Jura.
author: MWS

text: “At this time a slight sleep relieved me from the pain of reflection, which was disturbed by the approach of a beautiful child, who came running into the recess I had chosen, with all the sportiveness of infancy.
author: MWS

text: Suddenly, as I gazed on him, an idea seized me that this little creature was unprejudiced and had lived too short a time to have imbibed a horror of deformity.
author: MWS

text: If, therefore, I could seize him and educate him as my companion and friend, I should not be so desolate in this peopled earth.
author: MWS

text: “Urged by this impulse, I seized on the boy as he passed and drew him towards me.
author: MWS

text: As soon as he beheld my form, he placed his hands before his eyes and uttered a shrill scream; I drew his hand forcibly from his face and said, ‘Child, what is the meaning of this?
author: MWS

text: I do not intend to hurt you; listen to me.’  “He struggled violently.
author: MWS

text: ‘Let me go,’ he cried; ‘monster!
author: MWS

text: You wish to eat me and tear me to pieces.
author: MWS

text: You are an ogre.
author: MWS

text: Let me go, or I will tell my papa.’  “‘Boy, you will never see your father again; you must come with me.’  “‘Hideous monster!
author: MWS

text: My papa is a syndic—he is M. Frankenstein—he will punish you.
author: MWS

text: You dare not keep me.’  “‘Frankenstein!
author: MWS

text: you belong then to my enemy—to him towards whom I have sworn eternal revenge; you shall be my first victim.’  “The child still struggled and loaded me with epithets which carried despair to my heart; I grasped his throat to silence him, and in a moment he lay dead at my feet.
author: MWS

text: “I gazed on my victim, and my heart swelled with exultation and hellish triumph; clapping my hands, I exclaimed, ‘I too can create desolation; my enemy is not invulnerable; this death will carry despair to him, and a thousand other miseries shall torment and destroy him.’  “As I fixed my eyes on the child, I saw something glittering on his breast.
author: MWS

text: I took it; it was a portrait of a most lovely woman.
author: MWS

text: In spite of my malignity, it softened and attracted me.
author: MWS

text: For a few moments I gazed with delight on her dark eyes, fringed by deep lashes, and her lovely lips; but presently my rage returned; I remembered that I was for ever deprived of the delights that such beautiful creatures could bestow and that she whose resemblance I contemplated would, in regarding me, have changed that air of divine benignity to one expressive of disgust and affright.
author: MWS

text: “Can you wonder that such thoughts transported me with rage?

text: I only wonder that at that moment, instead of venting my sensations in exclamations and agony, I did not rush among mankind and perish in the attempt to destroy them.
author: MWS

text: “While I was overcome by these feelings, I left the spot where I had committed the murder, and seeking a more secluded hiding-place, I entered a barn which had appeared to me to be empty.
author: MWS

text: A woman was sleeping on some straw; she was young, not indeed so beautiful as her whose portrait I held, but of an agreeable aspect and blooming in the loveliness of youth and health.
author: MWS

text: Here, I thought, is one of those whose joy-imparting smiles are bestowed on all but me.
author: MWS

text: And then I bent over her and whispered, ‘Awake, fairest, thy lover is near—he who would give his life but to obtain one look of affection from thine eyes; my beloved, awake!’  “The sleeper stirred; a thrill of terror ran through me.
author: MWS

text: Should she indeed awake, and see me, and curse me, and denounce the murderer?
author: MWS

text: Thus would she assuredly act if her darkened eyes opened and she beheld me.
author: MWS

text: The thought was madness; it stirred the fiend within me—not I, but she, shall suffer; the murder I have committed because I am for ever robbed of all that she could give me, she shall atone.
author: MWS

text: The crime had its source in her; be hers the punishment!

text: Thanks to the lessons of Felix and the sanguinary laws of man, I had learned now to work mischief.

text: I bent over her and placed the portrait securely in one of the folds of her dress.
author: MWS

text: She moved again, and I fled.
